40942317.review:
My recommendation comes with a few caveats, namely that if you're not a fan of walking simulators or interactive movie type games there will be nothing in Stories Untold for you. 99% of the game plays out like a Five Nights at Freddy's game, where your character is rooted to the ground and you can, at most, only interact with objects within your limited turning radius.

There are some puzzles, although I use the term loosely, because most of the time you'll be told exactly what to do and the real bulk of the challenge comes from figuring out how to accomplish it through the games somewhat obtuse controls. The best parts, gameplay wise, come in the form of sections emulating the old Commodore 64 text adventure games, and although these can be slightly frustrating initially, when you know what to do but not how to phrase it, I'm willing to at least let that part slide as a faithful recreation of the frustration found in those old games.

So, now that I've got all my complaints out of the way, why do I recommend Stories Untold? Mainly because it has a great atmosphere and is a genuinely immersive and intriguing little game; evoking the same feeling as old Twilight Zone or Tales of the Unexpected episodes. Are the (untold) stories particularly amazing or original? Not really, but nor were they in the episodes of those old shows; what sold them was their atmosphere and suspense, and the same is mostly true for Stories Untold.

The big downside, in this regard, is that the game peaks way too early, with the first chapter of the available four being the strongest by a country mile. The game keeps a relatively good pace afterward, but never manages to recapture the heights of tension and intrigue the first chapter sets up, leaving you with an overall experience that's fairly satisfying but probably nothing that will stick with you for too longer after.

In closing, for two hours of mildly spooky entertainment I'd say it's a little bit overpriced, (£5 for the full package would be nearer the mark imo) but if you're not put off by the lack of gameplay and are a fan creepypastas or stuff like that, you'll probably get your moneysworth out of Stories Untold.

40910223.review:

40872020.review:
I have really mixed feelings on this game and I wish Steam gave me more options than yes/no.  The short version is that the game is good, some of the puzzles are really hard/obtuse, some episodes are way better than others, and the ending completely changes the meaning of everything else you've seen in the game so if you hate twist endings without any creativity that were old after they were used the very first time hundreds of years ago, you might find this disappointing, but individual episodes of the game are better than others, and I can recommend the game on the merit of those segments alone.  That said I have a lot I wanted to say about this and I'd really like to just vent about this for a while, so here goes.  I do recommend this game simply on the fact that I enjoyed it until its very last episode.

[h1] There will be spoilers in this review but they will be marked.[/h1]

See, I don't want to recommend this game because the fourth episode and the ending kind of pulls the rug out from under the rest of it.  And I don't know if that's enough to ruin a game just for one, albeit major, aspect of it.  You can easily enjoy the other parts of the game on their own.  And I did.  I honestly see myself replaying [i]The House Abandon[/i] at some point since that was honestly the most effective, straightforward part.

The puzzles were interesting and immersive - for instance, you're playing a text-based adventure game but it's not just a black-and-white screen, you're in an 80s' bedroom with a computer using a tape hooked up to a screen - your playing a game where your character's playing a game [spoiler] where your character's playing a game.[/spoiler]

[h1]The House Abandon[/h1]

Ending aside, it's unfortunate that [i]The House Abandon[/i] is the strongest part of the game since it's the first segment.  It's the most straightforward.  Almost everyone's played or seen a text-based adventure game, or at least heard of one, right?  You know immediately how it's going to work and it's just intuitive. If you know how Zork works you'll have a decent idea of how things work in here.  The twist of the episode is interesting, [spoiler] where the fourth wall starts to break and you control elements of the 'real world' from within the 'game.'[/spoiler] I would give this segment an 8/10.  It gets its idea across, and there are a lot of fun little background details that really set the tone for 'being up late in the 80's playin' a text game.'

[h1]The Lab Conduct[/h1]

I really liked The Lab Conduct, but it's less straightforward of a concept than playing a text based game.  It has it's own feel to it, for certain, and playing as a 'volunteer' for a shady, dangerous lab experiment is an interesting concept for a puzzle game, especially once the nature of the experiment is revealed and things turn up to 11 (or at least a solid 10).  Using the old text-based adventure game interface again is a let down, since we just saw it executed in the horror genre so well in [i]THA[/i], but again once the twist sets in, things change immensely, [spoiler] and you go from using an adventure-game-style text parser to process an alien organism's memories, to using that same input to guide it in real-time.[/spoiler]  6/10, solid idea, slightly wonky execution.


Honestly, given I'm limited to Steam's binary yes/no review system, I can recommend the game based on these two chapters alone.  [i]TLC[/i] isn't as impressive as [i]THA[/i] but it gets its point across, albeit not as directly.

[h1]The Station Process[/h1]

[i]The Station Process[/i] is... an interesting concept.  It may be a bit flawed in it's execution, but running a numbers station in arctic temperatures while a storm rages outside and things start happening... It's a classic horror setting out of [i]The Thing/Who Goes There?[/i], or [i]The Shining.[/i]  The puzzles here sway a bit from the complex to the hopeless [spoiler](hope you like morse code!)[/spoiler], to a complete genre shift in it's last act.  Incidentally, while this story continues the implied overarching theme of 'aliens/hive mind invasions,' it's also where the real overarching plot starts to come through, in a way that's more obvious than in previous episodes, but like every episode so far it can also stand on it's own, though the obtuse puzzles seem to bring it down.  Notably, the microfilm is somewhat hard to read at times, making it a bit of a guess at times what letter it is you're supposed to enter.  I'd have to give this a 5/10.  

Before I completely get into ending spoiler territory, let me put it like this: the game's ending feels like a cheap twist you'd see in a bad fan theory or mid-2000s psychological thriller.  Any world building you thought was going on, any investment you have in these settings or stories, they don't matter. They're window trappings for a brain-dead simple morality tale.  This is the game's major flaw.

[h1]Ending spoilers begin here and continue for the rest of the review![/h1]

[h1]The Last Session[/h1]

Where it all falls apart - while the rest of the game is suggestive of some sci-fi/horror theme of alien invasions - is episode 4 - [i]The Last Session[/i].  Gameplay-wise, it serves as a sort of 'best of' of all of the previous story's puzzles, each one having a new twist for the ending.  For instance, we return to the setting and mechanics of the first episode but with a major twist/spin on it, telling a completely different story.  You're essentially quizzed on how well you could do in each previous section of the game with some minor exploration in-between.  And honestly, this is fine.  Throwbacks to old gameplay segments are a favorite of mine - the Robot Master rushes at the end of the MegaMan games, for instance.  

The story, however...All the buildup in the plot, with aliens and invasions and the implication that the world being overrun - is dropped for one of the most amateur plot twists in the book. In fact, the book probably has this twist in the chapter on "Twists You Shouldn't Use Anymore." Pointedly, [spoiler] it turns out that the past three episodes of the game were all a part of the main character's 80s pulp-horror anthology TV-series inspired crazy coma dream as his damaged brain tries to come to terms with the horrible thing he did: driving drunk, causing a fatal accident for his sister and a stranger, both of whom he chose not to save in exchange for trying to hide his liquor on the other drive to avoid blame.  That's it, the big twist is that the whole game is a cautionary tale about drunk driving - not to belittle anyone who's been affected by it's horrors (my grandfather got hit by a drunk driver in the 90s and he still hasn't been the same), but I expected more from a game with such a neat sci-fi/horror buildup. [/spoiler] In hindsight, it doesn't totally come out of nowhere, looking back there are some clues, but it also doesn't have a lot to do with what's going on in the individual episodes at face value, either.  

All-in-all, I'd have to give [i]The Last Session[/i] a 3/10.  The gameplay throwbacks are nice, but some of the logic leaps are insane, and the gameworld destroying plot twist overshadows what is otherwise an enjoyable game.  The presentation remains great the whole way through, maintaining the feeling of it's 80's setting in music, visuals, and sounds.  It's not bad to look at, it's standard unity graphics I feel, and it captures the feeling it's trying to portray well.

The ending is a huge letdown and I'm honestly up in the air rather or not I recommend this game. Is it fair to dislike something based on one element of it that isn't revealed until the very end of the experience? I don't have a satisfactory answer for that, and up until the game revealed its twist, I enjoyed it.  It was a fun ride even if the destination was narratively disappointing and left me wanting.

I found this game very disappointing. I was turned on to it by a Let's Play of The House Abandon(which now that I think about it is a really pretentious title). That part was great and I didn't mind playing through even after knowing what would happen. It's clever, effective and scary.

The other stories are garbage. They all have cool settings and it seems like something cool will happen but instead they build up mystery but then have either unsatisfying or ludicrous endings. Then they try and tie it all together and it's just a mess.

On a technical level also it's very bad. I recently played the text adventure Anchorhead from 20 years ago. It was great, you could enter all sorts of different sentences and the game would understand you. In this game you will see the sentence: "I'm sorry I don't understand" so often you will tear your hair out. 

Most of the gameplay is more like busy work, if you've ever wanted to experience the joy of googling information on an 80's microfiche machine then you've found the perfect game. Avoid!

This game is dreadful. I was misled by all the positive reviews into buying it, and how it has such positive reviews I really do not know. 
I could only make it 25 minutes before becoming extremely frustrated that the game would only recognize very specific commands and kept forcing me to repeat simple steps over and over again until I finally typed exactly what the game was looking for. How hard would it have been to just give the player a few options to choose from rather than leaving it seemingly open ended when it is, in fact, not at all open ended. After giving up on that I was forced to search for a guide online. Let me just say this, if your game is so vague and designed so poorly that only 10 minutes in you need to search for a guide, it is seriously flawed. Once I had the guide and the game back up, I could only play for several more minutes before becoming extremely bored.
The gameplay consists of reading text, looking over at the guide for what to type in, then reading more text. Truly awful. I got this game on sale for $5 and it isn’t even worth that. Ignore all the praise, there are hundreds of other games that you could have MUCH more fun playing. I have a library of 100 games and I would rather play literally any of them.
If you want a quality “text adventure” go buy a real f*cking book at the used book store for a dollar.

40426107.review:
A short game anthology akin to 80s sci fi and horror? Sounds like my cup of tea, especially considering how much I enjoyed Lakeview Cabin Collection. I was excited to play this after seeing all its accolades and overall positive response, but I have to say I was disappointed with the end product.

There are four "episodes" in this "anthology" of point and click adventure games. Each one ties into an over arching narrative involving the main character. The problem is that the best one is the first, the House Abandon. It's moddy as hell, very creepy, and very effective. Although the scrolling text is FAR TOO SLOW. It can't be emphasized enough exactly how slow and eventually tedious the text scrolling becomes. There is for some reason no option to speed it up. Major, MAJOR oversight. I know they were emulating old school text based adventure games, but I could have done without the slow text. And this is a common problem, not exclusive to me since I played on a laptop that was not equipped to handle this game (severe input lag, low frame rate- thank God this is primarily a click based game but I'm not counting that as a point against the game since I am not well informed on computer specs). The mood of The House Abandon was effective enough that I pushed through to the end despite the slow text.

I thought this would be horror themed, but it's really not. The middle two chapters are very much sci- fi themed, and the concluding one is a culmination of all the episodes. The middle two are okay and kind of intriguing, but it's the ending that made the game unravel for me.

I won't get into specifics, but I am going to discuss the general plot of the game a bit, so be warned about spoilers ahead.

[SPOILER] As I mentioned, the final chapter completely undoes the intrigue brought about by the preceeding chapters. It was a major let down. 

The problem is that, in hind sight, there was no intrigue. With the way The House Abandon ended, I guessed what was going on with the protagonist, and I was right. I was confused by the science fiction chapters in the middle. But the final chapter gives the player a hackneyed, easy, and quite frankly stupid twist that left me with a bad taste in my mouth. This is in the very beginning of the chapter, but then the game continues on for far too long detailing the story's inciting incident. It renders the previous chapters utterly pointless, and also ends with, well, a non ending. Nothing is really resolved. It just ends. I'm not sure if the developers thought they were being clever with their twist, but like I said, I very easilypredicted what happened after finishing the first chapter. I was left at the end thinking "so what?" [/SPOILER]

I love the concept of this. A point and click adventure game that uses different types of puzzles in each chapter (basically levels) to convey its narrative. And honestly, I wouldn't be averse to playing a sequel. But the only way I will play it is if the story is more interesting and/ or unique. As it is, it's incredibly disappointing given how good The House Abandon episode is. Better luck next time, I guess.

Dans l'épisode précédent j'étais amoureux de l'ambiance du jeu, du côté nouvelle en jeu-vidéo de ce jeu à épisode, qu'en est-il après avoir terminé le quatrième et dernier épisode ? Attention, spoilers !

Et bien le soufflé est un peu retombé malheureusement : j'avais bien remarqué que les épisodes précédents racontaient un peu plus que ce qu'ils voulaient bien montrer au premier abord (typiquement, [spoiler]l'accident de voiture qu'on entr'aperçoit à la fin du troisième épisode[/spoiler]) voire même peut-être [spoiler]qu'on pouvait trouver des liens entre les épisodes[/spoiler] pour peu qu'on s'aventure à chercher un peu, mais ce quatrième et dernier épisode arrive vraiment avec ses gros sabots pour tout démêler. J'avoue que je ne vois pas bien l'intérêt de tout expliquer aussi clairement alors que c'est justement la [i]relative[/i] subtilitée des épisodes précédents qui m'avaient séduit d'autant que cet épisode introduit un élément très agaçant qui m'a fait personnellement totalement sortir de l'histoire : le moment où le jeu, tout en nous laissant le contrôle de notre personnage, nous oblige à effectuer certaines actions tout en nous laissant bien comprendre qu'il vaudrait mieux pas continuer ([spoiler]picoler et conduire, cacher la bouteille d'alcool dans la voiture de l'inconnu avec qui on a eu un accident plutôt qu'aller s'inquiéter du sort de notre soeur[/spoiler])... Résultat, un jeu qui m'avait happé grâce à son ambiance vraiment réussie est parvenu à me faire totalement sortir du jeu avec ce dernier épisode. Avouez que c'est con.

Difficile de donner mon avis général sur le jeu du coup : clairement, les trois premiers quart du jeu sont très bons et j'en garderai un bon souvenir, mais la fin m'aura laissé un goût amer... À la limitte, le mieux serait peut-être de se contenter des trois premiers épisodes, quitte à les écumer à fond pour découvrir tous les secrets, et de se passer du dernier épisode... Dommage.

40296364.review:
全4話の短編連作アドベンチャーゲームで、1980年代に一世を風靡したコマンド入力型のテキストアドベンチャー（主人公の行動を、キーボードから use key のように入力してゲームを進めていくジャンル）をモチーフとした作品。
[b][u]テキストと音声は英語のみ[/u][/b]。一話あたりの所要時間は1～2時間前後で、全話クリアまではおよそ5～10時間です。

エピソードごとにさまざまな仕掛けが盛り込まれたゲームですので、ぜひ予備知識なしで最後までプレイしてほしいです。
トレイラーやスクリーンショットを見てピンときた人は、まずは第1話がまるごとプレイ可能なデモを試してみて、気に入ったら購入するとよいでしょう。セールの際には割引もされています。
以下、購入にあたって気になる（であろう）点について、できるだけ内容に触れないように説明しておきます。

まず、難易度について。本作におけるテキストアドベンチャーは雰囲気作りが主な目的で、構成としてはかなりシンプルなものになっています。
往年の作品のような難解さはなく、ロード中やポーズメニューのヒントを読んでおけば、大半のシーンでは詰まることなく先に進めるでしょう。

次に、英語について。文章はおおむね分かりやすく書かれていますし、音声には設定で英語字幕を表示できる（さらに Esc でポーズメニューを開くと、字幕を表示したまま一時停止できます）ので、それほど高い英語力は要求されないと思います。
ただし、[spoiler]字幕なしで数字や単語の聞き取り[/spoiler]をしないといけないシーンもあり、ここはちょっと大変かもしれません。詰まったら[url=steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=892322683]ガイド[/url]を参考にしてください。

最後に、プレイ中の中断・再開ができないことに気をつけてください。話の途中でゲームを終了すると、同じ話を最初からやり直すことになってしまいます。十分な時間を確保してからプレイするようにしましょう。

それでは、Stories Untold の世界へようこそ。そうそう、システム要件の追記事項にあるとおり、ヘッドホンでプレイされることをお勧めします。

I'm always skeptical of games in which you're asked to play older, nostalgic forms of games. Always strikes me as a bit cheap, manipulative, simple. But Stories Untold uses simple surroundings to create a spooky, unsettling anthology that you really should try. Especially because it's a brilliant, movie-length interactive experience for ABOUT the price of a movie. 

Stories Untold is a horror game, yeah. But it only made me jump once, so don't worry. It's not THAT kind of thriller. It's more substantial, creeping, mysterious terror that you slowly sink into as you learn more about the desks you sit in front of. Get it. Get this game. Then come talk to me about it.

40217628.review:
[h1][b]Cool Stories Bro![/b][/h1]

I never thought I'd see a '80s inspired text based adventure game that's also got a gorgeous graphical interface, nor did I ask for it.

...but that's what I got with Stories Untold. Playing each of these 4 stories felt just like popping a new horror VHS in the VCR and bracing yourself for the next ride.

Many people think don't see beyond mullets and electropop when they think of the 80s.

But these stories untold nail it like no game ever did before. Combined with the clever gameplay design - smart but never taxing - this is an absolute must play (in your VCR).

40192375.review:
During the first 3 of the 4 stories of this game, I found myself fascinated and enthralled by the stories/gameplay that Stories Untold provided. The gameplay was not particularly difficult to progress through, but the presentation was excellent - each episode felt like a unique and strange story, with a slightly different gameplay style - the "text-based" adventure of Ep 1., the "Myst-like" point and click of Ep.2, and the meta-game puzzle solving (with in-game documents to read) of Ep. 3.

The last episode completely lost me, and blew my overall enjoyment of the title.

Not to spoil it (even though I don't feel there is anything worth spoiling), but Ep. 4 is a re-hash of the first 3 episodes, with an "After School Special" cliched Aesop being crammed down your throat in the most un-nuanced and heavy-handed way possible. There is no gameplay to speak of in Ep. 4, it is just a public service anouncement that you must watch (or alt-F4 out of, as I would recommend)  to "complete" the "game".

In retrospect, there are many elements in the first 3 episodes that foreshadow the "revelation" in Ep. 4, but it insults your intelligence so aggressively that you don't care when you see "what they did there."

Get it on sale - and don't bother playing Ep. 4.

39898877.review:
Stories Untold es un juego bastante atípico, ambientado en los años ochenta, en el que se cuentan 4 historias a priori independientes, de terror y suspense. La manera de interactuar y desarrollar la historia es a través de máquinas propias de la época. 

Es difícil definir bien como funciona su jugabilidad, y creo que parte de lo llamativo de esta obra es saber poco o nada respecto a la historia y también a las mecánicas antes de comenzar a jugar. Y precisamente, este último apartado es lo que a muchos les gustará y sorprenderá, y a otros tantos aburrirá, pues a veces es complicado encontrar la manera de avanzar, y si no tienes demasiado paciencia y no te gusta la manera de interactuar con el juego, al final acabarás dejandolo muy pronto. Sin embargo, si decides dejarte llevar, una de las cosas más sorprendentes es como cambia la manera de interactuar con los aparatos a través de las 4 diferentes historias, y que la jugabilidad está directamente relacionada con la historia. Es genial terminar una historia, y ver que en la siguiente, a pesar de sus limitaciones, la manera de interactuar es bastante diferente al capítulo anterior. Eso, sumado a que las historias están bastante bien, y que la historia final concluye todo de una manera muy interesante, Stories Untold se convierte en un juego muy redondo y bastante original. 

De todas maneras, en este aspecto no es perfecto, ya que aunque la jugabilidad es bastante cambiante a lo largo de todo el titulo, hubiera sido interesante profundizar aun más en ese aspecto. Sí, cada historia encuentra un tema diferente que tratar, y logra generar mecánicas diferentes que concuerden con esa historia, pero aunque al principio sea un cambio sorpresivo, a la larga se acaba haciendo algo repetitivo. También, una pega grande que le veo es que el juego está totalmente en ingles, voces y subtitulos. Si no tienes un nivel medio al menos, va a ser complicado jugar, ya que gran parte se basa no tan solo en entender textos en ingles, sino escribirlos. A veces se hace complejo entender algunos textos, y otras veces lleva tiempo escribir la palabra o frase concreta para avanzar.

Graficamente es bueno, sobre todo en cuanto a los modelados muy bien recreados, texturas e iluminación y efectos de luz. Por supuesto, tiene buena música ochentera minimalista y progresiva generada a base de sintetizadores y sonidos tipicos de la epoca, y un buen doblaje en inglés.

Terminando, recomiendo mucho este juego, por apenas 1 euro se puede conseguir y por ese precio, es casi obligatorio comprar y experimentar Stories Untold, no te dejará indiferente.

39587574.review:
[h1]¿Puede una aventura conversacional hacerte temblar de miedo? La respuesta te sorprenderá.[/h1]

"Stories Untold" es difícil de definir en lo jugable, así que empecemos por el envoltorio.

Se trata de una antología de relatos de terror, divididos en cuatro episodios que nos llevarán entre media hora y una hora cada uno (dependiendo de lo que nos entretengamos o atasquemos). Con un opening ochentero total que nos recordará a cierta serie de moda, cada episodio tendrá un desarrollo diferente, con giros al más puro estilo "The Twilight Zone". Por ejemplo, en el primero seremos alguien que vuelve a casa y se pone a jugar a una aventura conversacional en su viejo ordenador, en el segundo seremos los voluntarios para llevar a cabo un experimento, etc. Realmente quiero desvelar lo mínimo del argumento.

Esto para empezar ya me parece original, ya que no me suena que haya muchos juegos así, narrados en forma de antología dividida en episodios, y este sin duda ha logrado que me entren ganas de más. A pesar de esta división en episodios, el juego mantiene en todo momento una identidad propia y coherencia que une al conjunto en una sola experiencia que no querremos dejar de lado. Y es que, de nuevo como si fuera una serie, cuando terminemos un episodio no querremos más que empezar el siguiente, para ver con qué nos sorprende.

Ahora vamos al apartado jugable que, como he dicho antes, es difícil de definir.

De algún modo me atrevería a decir que se trata de una aventura conversacional rodeada de una interfaz gráfica, aunque no siempre es así. Cada capítulo del juego se basará en la resolución de puzles o en seguir unos pasos concretos para seguir avanzando en la trama.
Siempre en primera persona, y en la mayoría de los casos con una movilidad muy limitada, deberemos ir manipulando los objetos del entorno, así como introduciendo órdenes escritas en el terminal de turno, para ir logrando avanzar.
Estas acciones deberán hacerse de manera muy concreta, y en ocasiones acarrean cierta complejidad que me hacen pensar que quizá no esté hecho para todo el mundo. Y es que, sobre todo en lo que a escribir en un terminal se refiere, es relativamente fácil quedarse atascado por no estar haciéndolo todo exactamente como debemos. En cualquier caso el juego ofrece pistas e instrucciones en todo momento por el escenario para que sepamos cómo debemos hacer las cosas, mi consejo es que os fijéis muy bien en todo por si se os ha pasado algo.
El lado bueno de lo anterior es que cuando conseguimos avanzar resulta muy satisfactorio, y verdaderamente nos sentimos recompensados.
Aunque la recompensa sea adentrarnos un poquito más en la pesadilla que es cada episodio.

No puedo recomendarlo más. "Stories Untold" es un producto original y en cierto modo arriesgado, y a partir de ya quiero más antologías como esta. ¿Para cuándo la segunda temporada?

39568044.review:
Despite not particularly enjoying the ending (I really wanted it to be something else), up until that point, Stories Untold was absolutely gripping and a fascinating romp if only to get to the bottom of whatever the hell was going on.  While I don't want to give anything away, rest assured the end of the game makes perfect sense in accordance to everything leading up to it.  It's just somewhat of a let-down for me.

That being said, Stories Untold is a gorgeous game that takes the age-old text adventure and flips it on its old, wrinkly head to do something truly unique and marvelous to behold.  It is presented in a similar fashion to the Twilight Zone or Black Mirror, for you younger folks, in that there are 4 distinct episodes in the game that are seemingly/mostly unrelated except for a certain atmosphere and/or feeling.  All of it is set in the 80s (because of course it is) and each piece of archaic technology is so lovingly rendered that there's no way the devs (or at least the art department) didn't live through that era when games came in books and you had to program them into your machine yourself.  Each episode usually features some sort of text parser and if you're familiar with old Infocom text adventures, you'll blow through this in probably 2 hours.  I spent another hour achievement hunting.

Unfortunately, this also means that the same old issues with text parsers exist - limited vocabulary, very specific sentences or phrases that the game is looking for, etc.  However, it is highly unlikely you'll get stuck because of a syntax error - a little observation and you'll figure out what you need to do next.  At first, the game takes on a supernatural sort of feeling with the first episode, The House Abandon (play the demo to try it) in which you are plunked in front of an old tape-loaded computer, playing an ancient game.  As episodes continue, things get a little weirder, but for the most part, you are always grounded in one place, interacting with monitors and keyboards so don't expect any bullet dodging or running from monsters here.

What Stories Untold does well is subtle, but it's what keeps you in your seat typing away.  Each episode is presented with very little information given to you in terms of the plot or narrative.  Instead, things just start and you're constantly left wondering just what the hell is going on.  There's this constant hope that looms overhead that maybe, just maybe, the game is going to reveal something to you.  It's that constant feeling of something just out of reach that makes the game such a fascinating journey.

I honestly can't say a single bad word about it.  No bugs, no glitches.  The game does exactly what it sets out to do and does it with such a nostalgic attention to detail that it was very hard for me to put down.  I loved every moment of it... well, almost.  There's no reason for you not to try the demo, so go on and do that.  Despite my disappointment at the end of the game, Stories Untold is simply more than the sum of its parts and should not be missed.

So what was it about the ending I didn't like?  (I do not recommend reading this part unless you've already finished the game)
[spoiler]The writing was fine and the narrative was fine.  There's no way you could rip the ending out of the game and replace it without completely replacing the previous episodes.  I understand that.  My disappointment didn't come from execution, but only expectation.  House Abandon is so mind-bogglingly awesome in the way that it ends that I spent the entire game hoping that there was a supernatural element to the whole game.  This is exacerbated by episode 3 and its Lovecraftian tentacles dropping from the sky.  To end with "herp derp coma" seemed like a huge cop-out to me, as it is almost any time a narrative relies on "it was just a dream" as its twist.  Given that the three previous episodes only have hints and nothing truly explicit, I was so hyped up for the last episode, but almost immediately when it started, I knew where it was headed and was like "Oh god, no."  That's all.  So yeah, I don't know what else could have been done, but the format is awesome.  I just wish the game had gone in a different direction is all, but that's just me.[/spoiler]

Man is this game a breath of fresh air.
 On a platform like Steam riddled with cookie cutter Early Access games, DayZ clones and unsatisfying free to play games; Stories Untold really sets itself apart.

PROS:
-The atmosphere is truly haunting, making you feel like you're in your own personal horror movie from the 80's
-The story is a well written almost puzzle like narrative that makes you feel like an idiot for not figuring it out before the end of the game.
-The variety of gameplay in each episode makes each one feel like its own unique challenge. 
-The sound design in this game makes everything from the typing on your keyboard to the crackle of your radio transmitter feel so much more meaningful.

CONS:

-I had some problems with episode 2 due to poor user interface. Had to look up a way out of the internet.

Definitely buy this game. Its more than worth the price.

39296772.review:
[h1]A brief description:[/h1]

At its core it's a puzzle-based suspense/horror game. The puzzles vary slightly between each episode; there are four episodes in total. Each episode has its own puzzles.

[h1]Why I recommend it:[/h1]

I wish I could mark this game as "recommended only if you get it for less than $5.00". If you can get this game as part of Humble Bundle or on a great sale, it's worth it. It's absolutely not worth the full $10.00 price. Is it worth getting and playing? Sure. Just not at the price they ask for.

Overall the game is very "Okay." Not great, not awful, just Meh. An interesting experience, especially for fans of horror games.

[h1]The Good:[/h1][list]
[*]Interesting take on text-based and point-and-click puzzles
[*]A unique spin on Suspense / Horror stories
[*]It's a very short game, which I think works well for the episodic puzzle nature of it
[/list]

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1266072089

[h1]The Bad:[/h1][list]
[*]The price - this game is about 2-3 hours long, at [i]most[/i], and I don't think it's such an amazing game that it deserves a $10.00 price tag
[*]I have one major gripe about the game: the difficulty of the puzzles in the 3rd episode - I did not want to decipher Morse code while squinting at the guide on the tiny screen. I immediately went and found a Steam guide because I was so annoyed with the entire puzzle concept for the 3rd episode. I also had some difficulty with the 4th episode because [i]I didn't know what the game wanted from me[/i] with certain commands, or that I was supposed to [spoiler]magically know that I had whiskey in the car and I was supposed to plant it in the other car. How the hell was I supposed to know that I had the bottle with me?![/spoiler]
[*] My opinion about the story and episodes:
[spoiler]The episodes are all connected together in one overarching storyline told (loosely) over each episode. The fourth episode ties it all together. I was severely disappointed by this format because I was happier approaching the game as four standalone stories. I think it would have been a more interesting experience to have four separate short stories instead of one longer story introduced very well in the 1st episode, barely brushed on across the 2nd and 3rd episode, then slammed in your face in the 4th in a poorly-done and ham-fisted way. The story itself isn't particularly good.

 I saw another review that described it as devolving into PSA about drunk driving, and I have to agree the drunk driving story takes away from the eeriness and cool sci-fi concepts of the first three episodes. I liked the random one-off alien story of episode 2, and the idea that "things" are attacking the planet in episode 3 (did anyone else see the giant tree-looking thing on top of the station?). The first three episodes felt ruined by the 4th. I understand what the developers were going for, but it just wasn't my thing.[/spoiler]
[/list]

39274854.review:
First episode was interesting if a little basic.

Second episode is impenetrable, annoying, and slow.  Voice acting is subpar.  Controlling the knob on the signal generator is unspeakably tedious, but you'll get to do it for several minutes.  

The text "adventure" portion punishes experimentation by forcing you to wait through the screen's i n c r e d i b l y   s l o w text updates.  You're not given much to go on, which is fine, but every incorrect command is rewarded with a pointlessly long, pointlessly slow error message.

When you do manage to guess a valid command (or go look at a walkthrough, which is what I ended up doing), you're rewarded with a loud screeching cutscene.

I get that pacing and slow-burn storytelling can a great thing, but this is just punishingly slow.  I'm literally spending more time waiting on the game than I am playing it.

I love that the nostalgic 80s vibe is super on-point.  I love old text adventure games, and I really like the idea of mixing them with these other "external" elements, but this  second episode is just the opposite of fun in every way.

I was going to make this review into a very pale imitation of the game's structure, but decided that that would only confuse readers (or worse, spoil the game).

Suffice to say, if you've played more than a few games, you'll know better than to believe that the game is as simple as it initially portrays itself - and it's a good one.

The only negative I have to say about it is that, sometimes, the text-based sections trip over themselves and make it almost impossible to solve w/o a walkthrough. If you can forgive that and like twisted plotlines, then this is a very worthwhile (albeit short) game at full price.

If you can't forgive bugs like that but like twisted plotlines, wait for it to go on sale.

If you don't like twisted plotlines, why have you read this far?

TL;DR: 8.5/10 - good game, w/ a cpl stupid-frustrating text-puzzles because (I'm guessing) the devs are trying to be simultaneously anal-retentive and artistic.

39174075.review:
I'm a huge horror/sci-fi fan. I bought this game due to "Rely On Horror" recommending it. I've never played a text based adventure game in my life. The first 3 episodes are great but the 4th ruins the game. Here's my quick review:


[list]
    [*]Episode 1 shows you the text-based ropes and sets a spooky tone. Some really clever interactivity here.
    [*]Episode 2 is infiinitely more confusing to navigate than Episode 1 but it has a cool story. I had to look up how to do the first actions to progress the game but the complexity makes sense for the plot.
    [*]Episode 3 has really complicated puzzles/text entry. I had to look a few things up because I'm absolutely awful at [spoiler]deciphering morse code[/spoiler]. The story and sense of dread are GREAT! This is by FAR the best episode.
    [*]Episode 4 negates any fun you had in the previous 3 episodes. I can't tell you much without spoiling it but I wouldn't have even bothered playing it had I known the plot of Episode 4. A few commands were very unintuitive and I had to look up what text I needed to enter. Here's a spoiler summary if you're interested in why episode 4 ruins the game: [spoiler]Not a single horror/sci-fi thing happened in the game. It was all a guy watching horror/sci-fi shows on tv in a hospital while recovering from a drunk driving car accident which got his sister killed. The only thing left up for debate is if it was actually him drunk driving or if it was the cops framing him. Either way, turning a cool horror/sci-fi plot into a drunk driving PSA is really disappointing. I've seen countless bad horror movies try to do this same damn "NOTHING REALLY HAPPENED/IT'S ALL IN THEIR HEAD" plot twist and it's just as disappointing every time. Had I known it was going to be this awful story telling trope, I wouldn't have bothered wrestling with the horrors of text-based gameplay.[/spoiler]
[/list]

39172413.review:
Holy sh*t. Plot-wise, this is absolutely one of the cleverest and most intruiging games I have ever played, second in ingenuity only perhaps to Dr. Langeskov, The Tiger, and The Terribly Cursed Emerald. Gameplay-wise, it left a little to be desired; many of the actions players need to take are unituitive and their answers aren't always clearly hinted at. Some of the controls are additionally wonky; for example, there are multiple points in the game during which you have to "turn" a dial to get to high numbers by pressing and holding the mouse. This mechanic was reliably irritating, as it takes a wholly unecessary amount of time to reach most of the required numbers. What's worse is that during these scenes, a narrator is CONSTANTLY harassing you to hurry up -- this despite the fact that it is LITERALLY IMPOSSIBLE to complete the task any more quickly. 

That being said, I found the game EXTREMELY enjoyable; I would guess that most people, like myself, played Stories Untold in a single session, lasting less than 6 hours total (and that's if you REALLY take your sweet time). The first two episodes are distinctly creepy and sinisterly mysterious; the third is merely intruiging; and the fourth will completely blow you away. 10/10 would highly reccommend.

39132282.review:
I wanted to like this. It looked interesting and quirky and a little different from the average game. And it is, but it is let down  for me on two accounts. Firstly the ridiculously slow scrolling of the text with no apparent way to speed it up. That problem is multiplied by the second issue of a text parser that only seems to accept very specific commands at times. Now I played text-only adventures back in the eighties and they were frustrating back then but surely nowadays a game should be able to handle slightly different ways of saying the same thing. These two issues combine so that if you don't guess the exact phrase required, you have to wait while the slowly scrolling text tells you that it doesn't understand the command. I guess they are probably trying to recreate the eighties vibe but for me this just sucks the enjoyment out of what should be an entertaining game.

It really is a shame as I like the underlying idea and concept, it's just that the execution makes it so hard to like.

39035239.review:
This is definitely a case of love it or hate it, and I definitely love it.

The presentation of the game is top notch (although a few of the [spoiler]first person sections[/spoiler] have a horribly small field of view). The Interface is just incredible to look at. The team definitely had a clear idea of the aesthetic they wanted and I think they nailed it. Story telling is usually equally incredible, but a few scenes do fall a little short of subtle. Those can be forgiven, I think, because of how high quality the rest of the experience is.

HOWEVER

The game is very short, some of the text-adventure navigation is questionable, and with an asking price of 10 dollars, it's hard to recommend to everybody. If the game is on sale and you like text adventures, you would love this. If you've never played a text adventure, I'd definitely say try it. If you know you hate text adventures, give it a pass.

Lastly, the ending is definitely divisive. I don't love the ending, but it also didn't ruin the experience. My girlfriend loved the ending, so clearly there are varying opinions about it. I think even if you hate the ending, it's worth playing the game for the rest of it.

38930829.review:
Long, long ago, in an era occurring only slightly after the death of the last dinosaur, there were these ancient artifacts called - wait for it - "text adventures".

   They were among the very first "video games", even if they barely resembled the infinitely more snazzy products we now refer to by that name. The earliest examples of this genre of gaming didn't even have GRAPHICS, for cryin' out loud! They were no more than words...on a screen...which you interacted with by typing MORE words on the screen. Crazy, right? 

   But it's true: there was indeed a time in our darkest past where, if you wanted any level of immersion in a game deeper than one white bar hitting a dot towards another white bar (hello, Pong!), you were pretty much stuck with your imagination doing ninety-nine percent of the work for you.

   Let's face it: it was practically child abuse, by today's lofty standards.

   Fast forward to the year 2017, and what's this? Some game developer calling itself No Code (a double entendre, I presume) releases a four-episode game called Stories Untold, which at least partially carries on in the spirit of such text adventures...before adding some significant multi-genred twists, and a substantially more varied and modern visual interface.

   The most common viewpoint given in the first three episodes, at least, is that of the player themselves seated at an old-school desktop computer into which you can type commands, and for the first of the four episodes that's literally all that you can do. As the episodes progress, however, the player's interactions expand to other objects/machines about their workstation, which must also be fiddled with to make headway. 

   It's all quite clever, really; even if I ultimately found myself favouring the first and most "traditional" of the bunch, a spectacularly spooky number entitled The House Abandon.

   I first played this episode as a standalone game/demo quite some time ago, at the behest of a friend who generally plays neither horror nor text adventure games. It was available for free on a game-sharing site, and my friend (who had only been brave enough to watch a YouTube walkthrough) thought it might be well up my alley. He certainly wasn't wrong; though I at first suspected he might have been, especially in his assertion that a hardened horror game addict like myself might find it genuinely SCARY.

   A text adventure? Scary?! I may well have wondered what drugs or alcohol this friend of mine had been scoffing, if I didn't know him as an all-but-teetotaller. He even mentioned a few occasions when the girl he viewed in the video visibly JUMPED in fright at what the game threw at her. Haha, indeed, I thought. Young, hysterical girlies on YouTube is one thing, but I'm a man in his forties and a hardcore horror fanatic, darn it all to Hades. Sure enough, a slightly harrowing twenty-five minutes later, I was tucking my tail between my legs and confirming to my friend how very right he had been.

   Unfortunately, this tone of terror gradually subsides as the episodes of Stories Untold progress, and the parser-based typing largely makes way for more familiar adventure game puzzling and even a bit of first-person wandering. It's still very well-done, and there's still a consistent aura of dread to proceedings; it's just a shame that the seat-of-the-pants intuitiveness of the first episode is replaced by no end of tricky code-breaking and pedantic instruction-following, placing the last three-quarters of the game in the territory of a more familiar and contemporary adventure-gaming style, as opposed to the sheer green-screen era goodness of the game's earliest moments. 

   Or, to put it another way: if you're as bad at puzzles as I am, you'll happily stumble your way through the first episode without needing to peek at a walkthrough, while constantly referring to one for all that comes after.

   It's also a shame that the brilliantly enigmatic ending of The House Abandon is not only explained, but almost OVER-explained by the end of the four episodes. The storytelling still remains strong throughout, but a part of me can't help but feel that the attempt to "link" the four episodes together into a singular storyline was a somewhat misguided effort, and it may have been better if they'd just told four unrelated tales.

   It's still an excellent game, overall, and can hardly be faulted for lack of invention. I'm certainly intrigued to see what No Code get up to next.

Verdict: 8.5/10.

(PS If you enjoyed this review, feel free to check out my two Curator pages: http://store.steampowered.com/curator/9284586-ReviewsJustfortheHELLofit/
http://store.steampowered.com/curator/10868048-Truly-Horrible-Horror-Games/?appid=398210
Cheers!)

38900366.review:
Après avoir relu quelques évaluations du jeu, il m’apparaît opportun de préciser que, plus que pour beaucoup de jeux, Stories Untold (SU) ne peut pas emporter tous les suffrages. Pas en raison de défaillances supposées mais en raison de l’intention de son auteur ainsi que des choix qui ont été faits pour faire passer cette intention.
Donc, oui, je suis d’accord pour dire que, surtout dans les deux derniers épisodes, il est assez difficile de trouver la bonne terminologie pour avancer.
Il n’y a pas de véritable puzzle non plus.
MAIS
C’est un jeu et la recherche du bon terme et de la succession d’actions correctes peut vite devenir une épreuve comme une autre. Une épreuve un peu différente de celles auxquelles la plupart des jeux nous ont habitués. Personnellement, j’ai pris la recherche du terme idoine de certaines phrases comme une défaillance des machines, ce n’est peut-être pas pour rien si les appareils avec lesquels le joueur dialogue sont archaïques. Les ordinateurs ont fait quelques progrès depuis le langage Basic des années 70, 80…
Quant aux puzzles, en effet, ils n’en sont pas. Il s’agit plus de séquences où on applique des consignes. Dit comme ça, cela paraît idiot, mais c’est loin d’être évident parce qu’on est projeté dans un « univers » dans lequel on n’a aucune clef, il faut les trouver en tâtonnant avec, toujours, la tension au ventre parce que – c’est là un des points forts du jeu comme beaucoup l’ont souligné – l’ambiance est très réussi. La musique, les sont ambiants et les effets graphiques font de chaque « puzzle » un moment fort. Sans compter qu’il y en a un ou deux qu’on peut qualifier de difficile… pourtant, on suit des consignes…
Pour apprécier pleinement tout ça, il faut s’abandonner, s’engager sans a priori. Ne pas comparer. C’est à cette condition qu’on peut sortir de SU en se disant que c’était une expérience. En d’autres termes, c’est comme aller voir un « film d’auteur » (j’abhorre cette expression !) plutôt que le dernier film à gros budget hollywoodien. Privilégier la surprise au confort bien gras.
Les évaluations que j’ai lues ne mentionnent pas un des aspects surprenants du jeu : chaque épisode a ses spécificités en termes de gameplay et je trouve que lui apposer l’étiquette « text-based » est très réducteur.
J’en conclue en regrettant qu’il n’existe pas (encore ?) de traduction car, même si l’anglais utilisé dans le premier épisode (la demo aussi) est très accessible, ce n’est plus vraiment le cas plus on avance dans le jeu (il devient technique et un peu plus élaboré) et cela pourrait frustrer les joueurs non-anglophones.
En tout cas, j’ai vécu une expérience bien singulière avec SU et je ne peux que recommander ce jeu à tous les curieux. Si vous vous attendez à ce que tout le jeu ressemble à la demo, laissez tomber ; si vous aimez être traîné dans une zone d'inconfort, précipitez-vous !

I paid $4.00 for this game and I would sugest purchasing at this price or at an equivelant price. I'm not sure I would have been satisfied with the purchase at full price.

Stories Untold is a mostly decent interactive story. It is not really a game by standard definition. The Atsmosphere is the strongest aspect of the experience, being able to acomplish a lot with very little. The story was also pretty well done until the ending, although I found the reveal obvious befole I was even halfway through the game, although milage will greatly vary based on people and their experiences, although others I know figured out the story around the same time. 

The biggest weakness this has is the puzzles, which aren't exactly puzzling in any way. Most of the puzzles involve following a reference guide and perfoming steps based on the information given, making it a puzzle game in the same sense as programing a VCR was a puzzle game.

The second weakness of this game was the ending (This may have mild spoilers). [spoiler] My opinions may be largely related to figuring out the twist of the story early, but overall I felt the last story just drags on with the plot, giving the impression that the game is more interested in being a long public service message than anything else.	[/spoiler]

It is also worth noting that being a linear story experience, there's not much to replayability in this game, so while it's a good 2 hour experience, once you've played it once, there's no reason to play it again.

38816842.review:
Stories Untold presents as a text adventure with graphical elements, but is primarily a first person puzzle game akin to [i]The Room[/i], with the occasional text adventure or first person exploration section. It contains some really great writing and atmosphere.

The story starts out strong but eventually undermines itself with a twist which is less interesting than what was originally presented. The final episode is tedious as hell. It explains what's going on in the first 5 seconds, yet proceeds to drag you through an extensive exposition which just feels like going through the motions.

There are technical issues. The system requirements are very high for an adventure game, especially one which appears to be a text adventure. The text prints out very slowly on the screen with a typical laptop CPU. This game should have been optimised before release. 

There are design issues. In text-adventure scenes, you have to wait for the same text you've already read to slowly print out every time you return to a location you've already been. There is no way to skip this animation. There is also no way to skip any cutscenes or dismiss any dialog. Compounding this, there is no save game feature - you have to play each episode in a single sitting.

In the final episode, the text parser becomes very pedantic about which keyword you need to progress. The designers did not try very hard to make it robust to synonyms. Therefore, this game suffers from an issue which has plagued text adventures since the 1970's - the player knows exactly what to do to progress, but the game frustratingly won't allow them to do it.

There are show-stopping bugs. There is a point in episode 4 where a required switch becomes inoperable if you hit it too early. But because the game revolves around switch and lever puzzles, it's not apparent there's even anything wrong. This bug has affected many people, according to the forums, yet wasn't fixed. I had to restart the episode over from the beginning. Twice. This sealed my opinion of the game.

I enjoyed this game up until the final episode, where a combination of design oversights, dull writing and bugs infuriated me. Logical or not, we tend to enjoy an experience as much as we enjoy how it ends.

38772007.review: It's probably the most impressive and captivating experience I've had playing an "adventure" game. I've bought it after having read a lot of praises from various sources but without knowing exactly what to expect. The fact that it was inspired by old text adventure games immediately captured my attention, having played a lot of them during the eighties. The presentation and attention to detail is incredibile, a work done clearly by people of superior talent. But after the first chapter a big "meh" resounded in my head, mainly for two reasons. First the parser was very poor, I was expecting a lot more in this regard and second the story itself, while somewhat original, in the end appeared to me no more than a spooky novel for teenagers. I decided to move to the next chapter anyway and luckly my first impressions were totally wrong. Everything is connected and is a part of a bigger scheme, as the story unfolds everything start to make sense and literally makes the player live a surreal and disturbing experience. Nothing must be taken for granted in this game and the ability to constantly surprise the player without cheap "methods" is one of its most amazing aspects. In the end Stories Untold is the most refreshing and "mature" (from a design, aesthetic and narrative point ov view) that I've played during 2017 and I highly recommend it to everyone but especially to older players who can understand all the references and the zeitgesit that the game so masterfully depicts.

38770021.review: All 4 stories are great and tie in together very well

38767482.review:
I had such high hopes for this after the first two episodes. They were short, tense, and just the right amount of interactive, and fascinating to boot. Unfortunately, the third episode was a fucking disaster, an exercise in pointless frustration. If you like squinting at a blurry microfilm and working out what to do next based on elaborate code protocols I can't stop you, but it absolutely broke immersion for me and by the end of the episode I didn't give a shit about the plot. By the way, you can hold the right mouse button to zoom, which they don't tell you in the game, and which only helps a little. Fourth episode provided totally unnecessary exposition on the first three episodes, and provided an overarching story that the game didn't need and that I didn't care much about. It mainly frustrated me some more. If you're going to get this game anyway, get it on sale and play only the first two episodes.

Other qualms: a text-based game that doesn't account for alternative keyboard layouts, and doesn't let you change the keybindings for first-person movement controls. I had to switch to QWERTY for the first-person sections and then back to Dvorak for text entry. The game also doesn't respect basic conventions of text interfaces, like Tab switching text fields, so I had to move to mouse and then back to keyboard quite a bit while I was figuring out the puzzles. A weirdly specific final puzzle that requires you to [spoiler]not only click the tape recorder, but click a specific button on the tape recorder, while unable to read the button labels[/spoiler]. No way to save in the middle of an episode, so if you quit, you have to start over. And the cutscenes are unskippable.

Basically a 4/10, 9/10 if you ignore the ending half of the game. It's a terrible missed opportunity -- a series of four independent episodes that were only thematically connected would have been much better.

But I pushed through, thinking the ending might redeem it. Honestly, it didn't. The ending wasn't bad; it didn't live up to the glory of the first chapter, but it didn't make me want to sigh for the next twenty years like the second and third chapters. It's just that those two chapters were so god awful that no ending, unless it was absolutely excellent, could have made that slog worth it. 38222995.review:
6.5/10

Stories Untold is many things, most prominently a text-based adventure game. It weaves a wonderful tale, meshing gameplay and story in a way that many developers dream of. The final act, particularly, is astounding. Production values and sound design are high, and I can recommend the game without too much hesitation.

However, Stories Untold contains the most irritating aspects of adventure games. Often you'll find yourself typing various commands in at the prompt, over and over, without any of them being the ones that the game is looking for. Sometimes, most notably in a scene taking place at a party, it's entirely unclear what your character is supposed to be doing. In one particular instance, I was supposed to go into the kitchen from a hallway. However, the description of the hallway, even with additional details gleaned from using the "look around" command, made no mention of a kitchen. Another irritation was the usage of a microfiche in episode 3. Even after optimizing the focus, I was unable to make out many of the characters I was supposed to input into the computer. The game mentions in a tooltip that finding the right command is "part of the fun," but I certainly wasn't enjoying myself.

One could make an argument that the adventure style of the game ties in with the story as a whole, and that might be a compelling argument. However, I think the game might've been just as powerful if the developer used a "multiple choice" technique at each prompt.

38207609.review:
[h1]Stories Told[/h1] [SPOILER FREE]

Le avventure testuali sono uno dei generi di videogiochi più datati. Prima delle avventure grafiche c'erano infatti le avventure testuali (Interactive Fiction, qualcuno ha nominato ZORK?) che, tramite un parser, più o meno limitato, portavano il giocatore a scoprire storie leggendo, come un libro ma interattivo, basato sulla logica. Stories Untold già dai primi minuti si mette in mostra con tutti i suoi riferimenti nostalgici agli anni '80 dagli oggetti in scena alla colonna sonora, dallo stile grafico al logo del gioco stesso che richiama quello di Stranger Things. Il gioco è diviso in 4 episodi che si susseguiranno a delineare una storia. Durante il primo episodio ci troveremo davanti ad un monitor e ad un computer che richiama incredibilmente lo ZX Spectrum; parte qui l'avventura testuale, non nel nostro monitor, ma in quello all'interno del gioco stesso e già questo fa intuire la sua linfa da metagioco. Ogni episodio aggiungerà meccaniche che l'episodio precedente non aveva andando a complicare ma anche a rendere più variegata l'avventura. Non dirò altro in quanto scoprirne il funzionamento è parte intergrante dell'avventura e dire troppo potrebbe andare a minare l'esperienza, il piacere della scoperta. La durata totale dell'opera varia a seconda del tempo che metterete a capire come funzionerà il gioco, 2 o 3 ore basteranno comunque per gustarsi il titolo appieno. L'arco narrativo si infittisce di mistero proseguendo nella storia con una scrittura degna di nota ed un doppiaggio altamente curato. Il titolo di NoCode è un fantastico esempio di interactive storytelling, un coraggioso esperimento che dimostra che con la creatività anche un genere ormai morto può essere riportato in vita. Per i meno avvezzi alla lingua anglofona però ci sarà un ostacolo, manca totalmente una localizzazione italiana il chè, specialmente nel terzo episodio dove è fondamentale ascoltare, renderà difficile anche risolvere gli enigmi, seppur basilari, se non si riesce a capire i dialoghi. Un racconto sulla responsabilità delle proprie azioni, sul senso di colpa e sull'accettazione dello stesso che porta alla riflessione una volta terminato il viaggio. Senza sè e senza ma, un titolo sperimentale, una perla, che non fa altro che arricchire la nostra libreria e le nostre personalissime esperienze.

38167875.review:
Spoilers.

The early game masterfully demonstrates how engaging a text-based game can be, but the final segment completely mishandles it showcasing all of the platform's flaws.  "The House Abandon" occasionally frustrated with head-scratching commands, but never made you complete tedious details to fulfill an action, e.g., "Turn on Generator" works rather than "walk up to generator" "flip off circuit breaker" "turn on fuel valve" "flip open switch cover"... etc..

The fourth chapter DOES THIS.  The game's final boss is essentially making you act out the entire process of getting into a car, starting and driving it.  There are dozens of actions that go into this, thankfully the devs mercifully only make you choose about ten. Interestingly, the first chapter seemed to understand this minutia is hopelessly dull and didn't make you plod through the same tedium to turn off and exit the car.

Many more gripes related to the story that the top negative reviewers already cover nicely.  Great early game, but a miserable final chapter in both quality and gameplay.  Overall, the ending was so poorly executed that it even soured the first half that I loved.  5/10

38157003.review:
Completed in 9 hours. Amazing. The first 3 episodes seem like disconnected, but interesting, indie-horror stories. They each get creepy and have little twists, but nothing too spectacular... but then the 4th episdode... wow. That's when everything comes together in a horrifying conclusion. The three disconncted episodes connect. Everything goes off the rails. If you've been paying attention, you notice the little clues throughout all three episodes that are now meaningful.

This is very much a paying attention, lots of reading, getting "into the story" game. The more attention you pay, the more you explore your options, the more you'll get out of the game. Each episode is linear, with puzzles. I found all but one of the puzzles quite do-able without looking for help. The one exception I probably could have solved if I payed better attention.

I got the "got all achievements" achievement but there are still 3 hidden achieves so clearly I missed out on exploring a few places.

At max resolution and max details, the game chugged. The text on the computer screen in the first episode took ages to refresh and type, and opening video was skippy. I do have a very large high-res monitor, but still, I find it odd with such a simple game, I had to run in a lower resolution in a window with graphics turned down. The edges of the screen were cut off and I had a hard time hitting buttons on some of the puzzles, I had to click to zoom in, and when I un-clicked and it zoomed out I could briefly see the button I needed and click on it.

Nie polecam tej gry, ale muszę przyznać, że pierwsza część jest pomysłowa i zachęca, aby od razu zapoznać się z resztą. Niestety dalej twórcy gry popełnili wiele błędów, główne problemy to:
1. słaby projekt gry i łamigłówki - niby rozwiązujemy jakieś zagadki, ale prawie w każdej sytuacji algorytm mamy podany na tacy, a czynności, które musimy wykonać są powtarzalne i szybko się nudzą; chyba już lepiej było pozostać przy trybie tekstowym, który choć prosty, przynosi jednak najwięcej satysfakcji;
2. niezbyt ciekawa fabuła - zrobiono tu wiele, aby wzbudzić i utrzymać nasze zainteresowanie, ale ostatecznie okazuje się, że treść nie jest zbyt oryginalna i to psuje końcowy efekt; scenarzyści zdecydowali się na wariant, w którym pierwsze trzy części miały wykreować atmosferę niesamowitości, a ostatnia służy temu, aby wyjaśnić, o co chodziło - problem w tym, że to wyjaśnienie jest znów podane na tacy, dość banalne i nie pozostawia żadnych niedopowiedzeń, więc nie mamy też ochoty wracać do pierwszych części, żeby samemu odtworzyć historię na podstawie rozsypanych tam tropów.
Ostatecznie więc trochę szkoda tych 2-3 godzin, które są potrzebne, aby skończyć tę grę - nie jest ona tak innowacyjna, jak z początku mogłoby się wydawać. Dotyczy to zarówno jej projektu, jak i samej historii. Niemniej z pierwszym jej rozdziałem warto się przy jakiejś okazji zapoznać.

____________________________________________________________
REVIEW ON COMPLETION
____________________________________________________________

Okay cards on the tabe, i freaking love this! This Game was so good! This is my kind of game!

Never really played text based adventures but it appealed to the hard core old school nerd in me. Getting into the game, i loved the retro look of it all, i kind of wished that it was just the House Abandon, not looking at it ON the computer screen if that makes sense? But that being said it was cose yet creepy at the same time.

Episode 2 and 3 were by far my favourites, where the story tellers actually try to convince you that you're actually seeing an Alien invasion (which was freaking cool) Episode 2 in the lab was more techcy were as episode 3 was more code breaky, and it resuted in me writing things down and then tapping away at the keyboard like a tech pro. These parts actually make you feel smart

Episode 4 was THE TWIST. And all in all, i liked it. VERY life on mars cross bred with stranger things. It's a love letter to the 80's with the music score to match. 

Quibbles. Episode 3 towards the end, while i enjoyed the puzzle aspect, i thought it was lifted straight from the early stages of Conarium. Whether by design or mere chance is anyones guess. 

Episode 4, while i adore the idea of this is all in James' head while he slowly tracks back to reality, i do kind of wished they had carried on the alien invasion thread, that would have been nice.

Now for the Critical bit.
This game really spurs you on, and drags you and holds your attention which makes the game very enjoyable and very playable.
However! It has No replayability. Once you've played it, that's it. You know what to do, the game doesn't alter its approach and randomise settings and solutions, so as a reult this game has one play through to its credit which is a great great pity. I would love to play it again, but it wont be as enjoyable next time as i've already done what i need to do and know the solutions.

Overall freaking awesome, glad i payed it

Definitely one of those "if you like that sort of thing, you'll love it" experiences. In other words, this game is not for everyone. Anyone who has never played an old school text adventures, anyone who doesn't like (simple) audio, visual, and number puzzles and anyone who doesn't like games with dark endings should pass.

However, if you liked those things, if you like Gone Home or Her Story, then this game might be for you. It's short and there are walkthroughs available if you get stuck. If you have epilepsy or photosensitivity to flashing lights, don't play this game.

And avoid the forums at all cost in order to avoid spoilers.

37872742.review:
Stories Untold is the modern implementation of interactive-fiction, and it absolutely hits the atmosphere out of the park. I initially feared that the added atmosphere would take away from the imagination of the story, instead it amplifies it greatly, driving a sense of urgency or dread in a story, that I'm not sure I would have otherwise.

It certainly leaves a lasting impact--one that makes me mull over the stories even after putting away the game. Frankly something other interactive-fiction never managed to do.

However, if I do have one criticism of the game, it's that it is by far too short. I would recommend grabbing this during a sale, as the amount of content, as great as it is, runs short of how much content I would expect in a game of this price.

37852569.review:
Steam sólo permite calificar en "bueno" o "malo", cuando un caso como este requiere ciertos matices. Lo voy a poner como Recomendado porque en gran parte sale ganando y es una muy buena experiencia.

Tenemos a nuestra disposición cuatro episodios, cada uno con alguna mecánica y propuesta diferente. En todos hay puzzles de diferente dificultad pero en líneas generales nada demasiado complicado. Quizás puede resultar confuso atinarle a algunas secciones en las que debemos escribir acciones por lo limitado del diccionario del juego, y el hecho de que en algunas instancias debemos ser muy precisos con la cadena de acciones y en otras no.

Personalmente mis favoritos fueron los episodios 1 y 3. El tercero consiste en ir descifrando mensajes emitidos por una radio e incluso algo de código Morse. Fue una experiencia muy tensa e interesante.

El episodio 1 tiene un notable manejo del suspenso, es un excelente inicio para el juego.
El segundo episodio me gustó, tiene un desarrollo dinámico y se pone intenso. Quizás se me hizo un poco larga la primera parte con los instrumentos del laboratorio, pero nada que me haya sacado de la experiencia.

Creo que el problema está en el episodio 4. Se pone muy en modo walking simulator y hay unas cuantas decisiones puestas ahí que no terminaron de convencerme. Es una pena porque el último capítulo termina quedando muy pretencioso, dandole un bajón al que venía siendo un gran juego.

Más allá de la decepción en el episodio final, creo que los primeros tres son muy sólidos y disfrutables. Hacen a nivel general un juego muy recomendable, y por esos tres le doy mi aprobado.

Ez a játék egy igazi élmény.

37721705.review:
TL;DR get on sale.

Stories Untold is a short narrative presented through 4 episodes, each with varying gameplay. These segments range from text-based interactions, to performing experiments, to deciphering morse code (with a lookup chart available, of course). Many gameplay elements are similiar to those you'd find in a puzzle game, and I'd say gameplay was probably the best part of this game.

The story itself wasn't anything special (it didn't have to be) but the game tried to present it in a way that made it seem more interesting. I personally don't think it worked; I wasn't involved or invested in any of the characters (because, for one, there weren't really any characters presented) so I didn't particularily care about the outcome. I was actually enjoying the red herring plot more.

Overall, I'd say it's a decent game worth picking up while on sale. It's style and presentation are great, and it tries out some interesting ideas, but full price cannot be justified by these things alone for a game that took me only a little over 2 hours to beat. Get upwards of 66% off.

37697143.review:
Stories Untold is part suspense, psychological horror, sci-fi, and mystery.  It has an authentic, light-handed 80s nostaglia vibe; it harkens back to the days of cassette tapes, text adventures, and alien conspiracy theories.  It takes place in 4 episodes.  Three of these episodes are different set pieces with a common thread.  It is not readily apparent what the common thread is, but it is substantial enough to feel as you progress. 

The first episode is presented as a creepy text adventure being played by the protaganist.  The is a psychologicqal twist to it that puts you on the edge of your seat, on pins and needles as it draws to a concolusion.

The second episode is an alien conspiracy/sci-fi light scenario.  It has an X-Files flavor to it.  Again you play as the main character carrying out experiments of questionable nature.  You are left to wonder why your are doing this, and being pushed to continue... It leaves the player wondering what the connection is, if any.  It ends on a very alarming and suspenseful note.

The third episode takes place at a remote arctic weather station.   Questions start to mount as you are taked with decrypting and relaying coded messages for an unkown reason.  Something has gone very wrong and you are left to simply do your job as things unravel.  The conspiracy theorys and sci-fi elements come crashing back, and there is significant tension leading to the end of this episode.

FInally, the last episode ties it all together.  There is no way to review the story here without spoiling it.  This episode also briefly revisits individual gameplay elements from the first 3 set pieces.  The game allows the player a chance to start making the connections before it is pieced together in front of them.  It is an uncomfortable, grim, and somewhat moving climax.  You may find yourself fighting the inevitable as you see it bearing down.  For me, the ending didn't quite take the direction I would have expected considering the previous set pieces, but that was OK.  The game doesn't give away what it is until this final episode when you realize what has happened and why you are doing these things.
Of particular note is how powerful it can be when seemingly inconsequential details from the previous episodes suddenly become meaningul in the light of the final revelations.  I found the game to be very clever when it came to these small details which it intentionally does not attract attention to, but if you find yourself immersed in the mystery of each set piece, you will likely spot and question them yourself.

Gameplay is at your own pace.  There is a small amount of learnings to use the mechanics of each episode, but this element is not overbearing.  Some may find it tedious to a small degree, but this process has a purpose to the story.
The mechanics themselves are mostly simple point/click/drag , with some text inputs and some FPS walking simulation.

Graphics are solid, as is expected from Unity.  Some portions seem to have an intentionally downgrapded quality to them, which can be attributed to story elements; or at least they can be excused under the guise of story.

Sound and music are good.  There is a solid early 80s synth vibe to the spacey music.  Voice acting ranges from the immersive feeling of the radio chatter at the polar station, to some almost typical deadpan British delivery.  Note that the deadpan delivery again can be attributed to story and may have been intentional.

Stories Untold is an experience.  It's also a short experience at about 3 hours to complete without a guide.  However, these 3 hours keep the story moving at a good pace and wrap it all up in a decent time.  Quality over quantity:  Stories Untold should leave a mark on you by the time it is finished.  After the game is over, the experience lingers as you reflect on all those clever details you either overlooked or dismissed as inconsequential at the time.  Like any finely crafted mystery, you can replay the story and really see that it was all right in front of you the whole time, but you simply had no idea.  It took time to put the pieces together and for the light to shine on the truth.

If you like psychological thrillers, creepy sci-fi horror with an 80s falir, point & click adventures, or emotionally charged stories, Stories Untold is a worthwhile journey.  Just remember to pay attention and question why, because the more you invest into the game, the more you'll walk away with when it's all over.
