37434400.review:
[h1] As Histórias não Contadas [/h1] 

O que você pode esperar deste jogo?
Bem, eu não sabia ao certo o que me aguardava quando iniciei este game. Eu pouco sabia dele (tinha uma pegada "anos 80", Stranger Things e Além da Imaginação...) O que é afinal esta aventura em texto com elementos em primeira pessoa e puzzles?

[h1] Os pontos positivos: [/h1]

* O visual retrô e elegante de uma época onde as coisas / a vida era um pouco mais ingênua e simples (final da década de 70 / início dos anos 80)

* A trilha sonora (é tão imersiva, especialmente esculpida neste estilo retrô) que de tão boa eu baixei e ouço enquanto faço outras coisas. Estilão mistério / scifi antigo

* A história não contada em si é realmente surpreendente (pelo menos pra mim foi). Existe um leve "plot twist" e o tema central é algo com que qualquer pessoa possa se relacionar e, por que não, até mesmo refletir um pouco

* O trabalho de vozes é realmente muito bom (tem voz? Tem sim) Os dubladores são extremamente competentes

* Jogá-lo com fones de ouvido e luzes apagadas é 70% mais interessante

* Você vai encontrar elementos de horror / suspense no enredo, mas não é exclusivamente uma coisa ou outra (eu não jogo games de horror porque eu não tenho estômago / coragem pra isso)

* As 4 histórias são únicas e não consigo me decidir qual eu mais gostei: [h1] O abandono da Casa[/h1]   [h1] O experimento de Laboratório[/h1]  [h1] O Processo da Estação[/h1]  ou [h1] A última Sessão[/h1]

* A forma como as histórias são tão diferentes, tão únicas e ao mesmo tempo se complementam tão bem. Adianto que o nível de dificuldade é bastante diferente entre elas

* As histórias são curtas o suficiente para que você não se canse ou enjoe delas, mas...

* O desafio / os puzzles. Este jogo não vai facilitar NADA pra você, mas ele é absurdamente justo aos atentos, aos observadores, aos curiosos. Você não vai precisar fazer deduções "sherlockianas" ou ter um conhecimento vasto em alguma área da Física pra poder resolver qualquer enigma - esteja atento, use a dedução lógica e mais SIMPLES porque T-U-D-O o que o jogo te der em mãos é o suficiente pra que você avance com a história

* Não é "sumariamente obrigatoriedade ditatorial" que você seja uma pessoa que se permita mergulhar de cabeça nas histórias e afunde nas imersões, mas vai ajudar bastante se você se permitir (bastante)

 [h1] Os pontos negativos: [/h1]

** Infelizmente o jogo está em inglês sem legendas em português (infelizmente porque acho que mtos brasileiros sem o conhecimento da língua adorariam jogar esta aventura em texto)

** Não há save manual e se você não andar [u]até o final[/u] de cada capítulo antes de sair, vai ter que recomeçar tudo de novo (o capitulo em questão). O jogo só salva ao final de cada capítulo. ACASO EU ESTEJA ERRADO POR FAVOR ALGUÉM ME CORRIJA

** Os capítulos são curtos demais deixando um gosto de "poderiam ter explorado esta história, maneira, ainda mais" (Lá atrás eu disse que isso era um ponto positivo, certo? A sucintez, a brevidade destas histórias é um ponto positivo e negativo ao mesmo tempo dependendo do ângulo analisado)

** Pode acontecer com vocês (aconteceu comigo) de clicar em algo ou chegar a uma conclusão de como resolver um puzzle e não acontecer nada na sua interação / decisão. Tente de novo. pode ser um pequeno "ângulo errado" em que você clicou ou mesmo o tempo que você levou na ação. (Isso é raro, mas aconteceu comigo 2 vezes)

** No 3º (TERCEIRO) capítulo POR FAVOR tenha em mãos [u] um papel e uma caneta / lápis / caneta marcador / giz de cera / carvão... [/u] qualquer coisa que sirva para escrever de forma confortável e rápida porque o jogo NÃO te avisa, mas algumas coisas que são ditas (use as legendas pra não se confundir / se atrasar) precisam ser anotadas. Quando vc pegar o ritmo do 3º capítulo isso fica mais tranquilo. Precisei reiniciar o capítulo 2 vezes porque perdi algo dito que precisava ter sido anotado (logo no começo do episódio o que causou pouco transtorno é verdade)

36839314.review:
Many people cite The Last of Us as a game where you do not want to do what you have to do at the end to progress. I always disagreed with that, as by the time that game was at its end I was already committed to protecting Ellie and no one was going to stop me.


This game, though? I really did not want to finish it. Somehow this game really got to me, and the ending effected me in unexpected ways. What this game was going for one hundred percent worked on me. I can not promise it will work on you, and this review might feel a bit overhyped, but its how I felt playing this game.


On top of that, Act 1 was legitimately the scariest section in gaming for me this year, the year RE7 came out. And it didnt do it with graphics, or grotesque imagery.

This is a very hard game to review, since its basically *all* spoilers. But, heres the thing: Act 1 is the Demo. Play the Demo. I think this game is more than the sum of its parts, and the parts are good! Its more than what it seems. The game is broken up in to four chapters, but I feel like playing this game in chunks is a mistake. (Though if you cant spend three hours playing a game, they offer convenient stopping points, if that is a plus for you). And yeah, the game is a short ~3 hours experience. But it is worth the price (which is cheap to begin with), and is a very unique game to come out this year that I feel is overshadowed by everything else that came out this year.


I nominated this game for the "Mom's Spaghetti" award because, once I finished it, I watched an LP of it, just to relive it again, through someone else's eyes. I recommend this to any horror fan out there and its usually the first game I think of when I think of great games I played this year.


If you truly feel ten bucks is too much, this game is sub-5 bucks on sale. Pick it up.

36834462.review:
I got into this game because people told me that if I enjoyed Stranger Things (I do), I would enjoy this.
Right off the bat, you've got a classic Zork-esque adventure which quickly takes a turn, and doesn't stop till the end (which comes all too soon, with the main story lasting only about 4 hours).
The pacing can feel a bit odd at times, especially when you find yourself stumped on a puzzle after having lots of momentum in other parts of the game.
There weren't any jump scares, but there were still a couple of parts that gave me a bit of a fright, and it was actually pretty exhilarating!
I'm usually pretty good at predicting what's going to happen in a game, but this one actually threw me for a loop with the twist at the end, and I was really happy about that.

All in all, I was really happy with this, and would recommend it to anybody into the 80's aesthetic, or just spooky sci-fi stuff in general.

36671015.review:
I put off purchasing Untold Stories, largely because I couldn’t get my head around what it was I’d actually be buying- there is a reason for that! Untold Stories comprises of four separate episodes, each utilising a mix of tried and tested mechanics in a refreshing and really unique way. Seamlessly blending point and click and text adventure game styles (among others) to build a really clever narrative.

Each stand-alone episode/story is presented individually, separately named and they all have distinct variations in location (bedroom, lab, weather station and hospital) and play style. However, they are increasingly self-referential and this culminates in a climactic ending that is well worth the 2-3 hours it will take to complete the game, including 13 achievements on Steam.

The game starts at a desk with an old computer and a cassette loading text adventure game that you proceed to play. Later, it has you using some seriously old-school equipment to complete puzzles. This all adds to the nostalgia whilst always progressing the story, nothing feels unnecessary. The puzzles are well constructed and logical but some of the controls weren’t immediately obvious. I spent a lot of time squinting at something illegible before realising I could zoom! I also found the text input required a bit too much specificity at times, but I always worked it out in the end.

The visuals reminded me instantly of Stranger Things, in that it manages to create a retro 80’s aesthetic that doesn’t feel overdone or contrived in any way. The environments are small but use clever lighting to add depth to the locations and are littered with items definitive of the era, all adding greatly to the sense of nostalgia.

Music was minimal but apt, accompanying sound effects that were used to help create some genuinely creepy moments. The dialogue was written well and convincingly acted, though this was only one storytelling technique used.

No Code did a fantastic job of making Untold Stories a truly unique experience, I haven’t played anything else quite like it. What makes it really brilliant is the way it utilises every aspect of the game to tell the story and add to the narrative. No pixel, mechanic or moment is wasted and I admired how cleverly everything was amalgamated.

After two playthroughs I can tell you that there is pretty much no replay value but the first sitting is definitely an experience worth having!



If you enjoyed this and would like to see my game reviews (and a bunch of other ramblings) in their natural habitat please visit my [url=www.rachaelbreartonwrites.com]blog[/url]

36667429.review:
[h1][i]Short Review[/i][/h1]
[h1]TL;DR at Bottom[/h1]
[b]Let me know what you thought of this review in the comments below![/b]

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1199655156
[h1]Verdict : [/h1]
[b][i]Less than scary, more than worth the full price[/i][/b]


[h1]Short and Sweet[/h1]
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1199655207
Four episodes. Three hours. Doesn’t sound like much on paper, but Stories Untold is one of the rare few games which can somehow manage to get away with having such short length, and there’s a good reason as to why. Whereas many games think that it’s necessary to pad the experience with half-baked content just to make sure it has a decent runtime, Stories Untold realizes that, while yes it’s important to get your money's worth from a game, that doesn’t mean it can’t be short. Instead of stretching their content to fill an eight hour campaign, they chose to build a condensed, yet powerful, experience with a story that’ll slowly unravel itself as you play. Not only does Stories Untold contain one of the best stories in any game I’ve played over 2017, but they made sure to keep each episode interesting. Without spoiling anything, the first episode involves you playing a particularly interesting text adventure game, the second has you setting up tech for a lab experiment, and the third and fourth feature you relaying military signals using a complex codebook. Each of these in some way impacts the narrative as a whole, helping you to understand the story and make more sense out of it, which is really useful because the story is a touch confusing once everything is finally revealed to you at the end. There’s little things too that add to the immersion in Stories Untold too, like on the first level actually getting to hear the mechanical keyboard your character is using, that make it all the more unique. There’s definitely an argument to be made as to whether or not this is actually a game, or more of an interactive experience. I’m leaning more towards the latter option, not for any particular reason other than that the game feels more like playing through a horror movie rather than a game, which honestly is one of the game’s many strengths. There really isn’t that much that I can say as most of the game, including mechanics, tie into the story some way. However, what I can say is that Stories Untold is the greatest mechanical and narrative experience that I have played over the course of this year, and is a definite contender for my 2017 GOTY.

[h1]Scary Without Being Scary[/h1]
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1199656663
What’s even more impressive about Stories Untold is that it manages to be a tense and uncomfortable experience without relying on jump scares almost at all. There’s a few in the first episode, and maybe one in the second, but after that you’re all clear. This is to its credit, few games are actually able to create an atmosphere that has you unnerved by things in the environment, rather than just being scared of the next inevitable jump scare, but Stories Untold does just that. There were multiple occasions, especially towards the end of the game, where I found myself tensing up, only to get through without actually encountering anything at all. The fear that you conjure up in your mind, a fear made of what-if’s and could-be’s, is terrifying more than anything else the game can create. So the game capitalizes on that, trying to make you think you’re going to get jumpscared only for everything to calm down, and this happens again and again throughout the game. So no, from a normal horror perspective I honestly can’t say that Stories Untold is all too scary per se, but that’s because they don’t need jump scares and screamers to send chills down your spine, they can do it with something as simple as footsteps.

[h1]TL;DR[/h1]
Stories Untold is the greatest mechanical and narrative hybrid of a game that I have played over the course of this year, and is a definite contender for my 2017 GOTY.

[h1]If you found this review helpful or entertaining then feel free to leave a comment and join my Steam Curator Group at  [url=http://store.steampowered.com/curator/9577715-Mudkips-Gaming/]Mudkips Gaming[/url]

36333953.review:
Like other reviewers, I would also give this a mixed review. It sets up a really compelling thriller with a lot of unanswered questions and great atmosphere, but the payoff is terrible. Mechanically, it learned nothing from other text adventures about being user friendly. You have to wait for the game to slowly type out the full scene with no option to speed it up. It has difficulty understanding your commands. And the third act can be frustrating because some parts are really hard to hear or see, and your ability to continue is entirely dependent on entering the exact right thing.

The fourth act is dreadful and ruins the story they had set up.

So If you can get this on the cheap, give it a go. It's not perfect, but I enjoyed it.

36332229.review:
Está procurando um jogo com climão de suspense e aquela cara de anos 80 no melhor estilo "Stranger Things"? Este é o jogo! Descobri ele no canal EDGE, do Alan Ferreira, no Youtube (jabá for free) e me interessei instantaneamente. 

O jogo consiste em 4 episódios que a princípio não parecem, mas que estão ligados entre si. Não dá pra falar muito sem dar spoiler, mas o final é bem interessante e amarra as pontas bem direitinho.

O primeiro episódio do game, The House Abandon, havia sido disponibilizado grátis anteriormente em uma versão menos acabada em termos gráficos e por si só já valeria a indicação. Trata-se de um jogo de terror text-based no melhor estilo que se jogava naqueles computadores dos anos 70 e 80 que você ligava na TV. O climão é sensacional.

Os demais episódios fogem um pouco da fórmula do text-based e focam mais na resolução de puzzles. À medida que o jogador progride, a história de background vai sendo desvendada.

O jogo não é muito longo, dá pra terminar com 3 a 4 horas de jogatina, mas vale cada centavo. Ainda mais se pegar numa promo como eu fiz. =)

NOTA: 9/10

36319927.review:
I loved almost every bit of this game. 
This was my first interactive text-based game so my words should be taken lightly, but I am now hooked. 
I of course know this genre has existed since the beginning of games, during a time when processing power was very low, and being able to develop with a low budget (same reasons for the creation of visual novels). 
I just gotta say this game has shown me the way.
I will now be hunting down every recommended interactive text-based game I can get my hands on. 

Also I have to admit, the big reveal did make me shed a tear.
It hit a bit close to home, so there's my bias for this.
While my personal life experience wasn't as grave or extreme as this story, without spoiling anything, I too have done something similar as this character, and the memory of it still has a deep grasp on me.

My only gripes would be too many times I found myself stuck.
Like the direction the game expected me to go was not very clear.
And even if I knew where to go, it always came down to me not knowing the correct command.
After looking at one of the guides on steam, I always ended up asking myself "How did that person figure it out?"
and I would spend some time digging around for clues I might've missed, which half the time I didn't find any.
So I'm left to assume the devs were hoping it's players already had experience in these types of games.
In other words, it wasn't really friendly to newbs like me to this genre.
After looking around, it seems like even veterans had trouble.

Either way.. Thank you Devs for making this game.
I will not forget this experience.
And will recommend it to all my friends.

36299719.review:
Recommended with one reservation. 
First, its a good game.  Could be an Excellent game.
Short, but very cool.  I loved what they did with the blend of old school text adventure and graphics.  My first computer was setup almost identically to how they had theirs setup, keyboard next to t.v.   Mine was Commodore 64 though.
I started gaming with Zork so it was a bit of nostalgia to do text adventure, which was fun, but that's where the single problem with this game comes in.  Near the end, there is a point in the game where the obvious word choice for an action simply doesn't work.  It was like the 'Enter the curtain' moment in Zork.  It takes you out of the moment.  Every logical word choice alternative simply doesn't work and I still remember the frustration.  
For me it was only this one spot that took the game from Excellent to just good, because what ended up working, which I had to look up on the internet, was simply bad grammar... or poor word choice I guess... it didn't really make sense to say it that way and saying it the way any native English speaker would say just didn't work.  Iit really took me out of the mood to hit a brick wall based on word choice.  If I were the developer, I'd fix this part.  It was the only part of the game I had to get help and that was disappointing.  
Overall, good story, I very much enjoyed playing the game, I got it on sale for $3 which I felt was a pretty good deal.

36287740.review:
This is one of those types of games that stay with you. That type of game that you love experiencing and when it's over you are overwhelmed by the feeling of wishing you could go back in time and play it again fresh.

 I felt like I was playing a new game instead of a new game with similar mechanics and gameplay as previous/recent games. The gameplay was so enjoyable that I wish every chapter were longer to have enjoyed that particular chapter's mechanics for longer. I promise you that there is not a single dull moment in this game. Even when nothing's happening you get to use your brain and get rewarded when you discover all the little puzzles that tie in to eachother by game's end. 

The story was incredibly well-written also. Stories Untold absolutely kept me on the edge of my seat and I found myself trying my hardest to pace out playing each chapter so that it wouldn't end too soon. Needless to say that strategy didn't work out so well as I ended up finishing the game within a couple days or so. 

This game is definitely worth playing through. New, exciting, well-made and memorable. This is the type of game I will be talking about to others. I can't say that I've had a game do this to me in... I honestly can't remember the last time a game has brought me to talking to others about it as this one has.

If you like 80's nostalgia, if you like thrilling perfectly-paced suspense and mystery with a big ole shot of horror. If you like a game that leaves you begging for more and trying to figure out what's going on only to perfectly wrap up by the end of the game in a way that leaves you sitting there amazed at how every little detail connects in every way. If you like new, fun game mechanics and using your brain and actually feeling rewarded by your discoveries, this game is for you.

36245998.review:
Overall, if you're interested in fun, spooky games and think this looks interesting to you, it's definitely worth playing through without knowing anything else about it. Otherwise here's my review.

The first chapter of this game is the best. It's one of the most fun horror experiences I've had in a while. Atmospheric and eerie, I jumped out of my seat, had dawning realizations and at moments I dreaded having to reach out and type even another word. I loved it. The developers knew how to use this medium effectively and it really shines.
 
The rest of the game, while I enjoyed it, was simply not as scary. The concept of switching settings multiple times and always having some kind of computer interface to interact with was neat, and they did do a good job. It was immersive, sitting at a computer and getting lost in the instructions and atmosphere (it's as if I have a lot of experience doing that in real life :D). The little vignettes unfolding where interesting and I grasped at every little bit of information in those first few chapters. Part of me wishes there had been ten chapters, draw out the stories with subtle hints and give us more vignettes in various horror scenarios, because what they did was fun and interesting. It just felt like a big genre shift away from horror and into (admittedly decent) speculative fiction. Maybe another, scarier vignette would have tipped the balance back to horror? I don't know. I do know that while enjoyable, the rest of the vignettes don't hit the same high. I think #2 and #3 aren't too bad but brought down a little by #4 tearing you out of the immersion completely for the story's sake. I was left craving more of The House Abandon, some kind of escape the room game switching you between finding clues in a house and doing a text adventure on an old computer.

There are other minor complaints and most other reviews cover them pretty well. Frustrating mechanics, instructions not telegraphed clearly, the overall story gives a YMMV vibe. For me that stuff keeps it from being an amazing game, but I'd still recommend it, because it was a really nice experience to play through. It felt kind of like reading a horror short story anthology, and I wish there was more. I don't see this as a game someone regrets playing, even if that first chapter truly is the best. If you are worried about enjoying it all the way through, get it on sale. Chapter 1 is more than worth the sale price.

36235671.review:
This game is basically an interactive creepy story told in 4 episodes.  It's unique in how it tells it.  A lot of it is text commands like, "go outside", "use key", "look around", etc. while your character uses a computer and the story plays out on the computer.  The game isn't just typing on a computer.  Sometimes you have to tune a radio, flip switches, and turn knobs.  Some parts let you walk around in first-person.  The setting takes place in the mid-80's so the environment and music is retro. It's not a super scary story but will have you on edge at times.  This isn't a horror game where ghosts and monsters come after you.  This is all about an interactive story that lets you play the main character.  It's not for everyone but if you like interactive stories, 80's themed stuff and creepy stories you should give it a chance.  I enjoyed it!  It starts out a bit slow but you'll soon find out that this game will take you for a ride.  

I will admit, I had to use a walkthrough on some parts.  It can be a little cryptic at times but just keep looking around your environment and when using text commands get used to using the "look around" command.

Pros:
Immersive storyline
80's themed
Interactive story (not a cheap point-and-click)
Can be completed in short time
Easy to get all achievements

Cons:
Had to use a walkthrough a few times.

36235603.review:
Stories Untold is a game filled with extremely intersting ideas that aren't all entirely well executed. This game consists of four seperate chapters, each having a unique story. I think that the first chapter is the best tonaly by far, setting up some really tense atmosphere. Due to the nature of the text-based adventures games that it replicates it is mechanicly light. The second chapter is a bit more mechanicly deep but I think it lacks a little of the tone that chapter one has. Chapter three is my least favorite, due to a large difficulty spike in the puzzle solving. I think it really derails the momentum that the first two chapters had build up however that problem could be something that not all players will run into. The last chapter was interesting but not reall as compelling as the first two chapter. All in all, I think this game is worth the price even though it stumble in places. 
7/10 "to much water"

Have you ever had someone recommend a game to you and you're all, "meh, I'll play it some time later". But they keeping asking you if you've played it yet but you haven't. Eventually you decide just play it to shut them up only to be pleasantly surprised? Good, because this is one of those games.

When I first started it, I was just going to give it a try to see what made it so fascinating. I was oddly drawn in when I first started, though slightly annoyed because the first segment had a text adventure game. I am not a fan of that genre. Alas, I did get through and glad I did. The remainder of the game was wrapped in a beautiful silk cloth of masterfully woven story telling with unexpected plot twists that weren't overly cliche or predictable. However, there comes a point in the game where you begin to wonder, just how much of this is real and what has been happening to you up to this point.

The three initial stories all seem to have nothing to do with each other. Fortunately, the developers have expertly tied them all together logically at the end of the game, bringing the story to a neat conclusion.

36219353.review:
I've played text-based games for nearly 40 years. This is bad, by any measure. 

First off, there is no consistency for syntax of commands. Secondly, the actual parsing engine is trivial. It doesn't allow you to do silly things, it doesn't give you any choices, or freedoms. The old text-based games were so elaborate, that it was almost like conversing with a modern AI. 

It's a boring, linear, uninspired, tedious game that forces you to do reptitive, mundane things and incorporates these into the story in the most ass way possible. 

The cherry for me on the shit sundae was the point in the game where it made you look into a flashing light that was merely there to make it harder to read the symbols you needed for a key code. 

It was at that point, where I lost all interest and remembered what it was like to play a game that doesn't force you to hurt your eyes, perform a tedious task, mapping or something that a fucking preschooler could do to occupy your fucking time. 

Save your money and download one of the myriad free text-based games that were evidently made by titans when you play shit like this. 

Talentless, boring shit. 

Fuck.

36184312.review:
A dread inducing horror game with an 80s synth soundtrack that doesn't quite stick the landing.

Pros:
 - Genuinely dread inducing gameplay.
 - Refreshing change of pace from jump scare horror titles.

Cons:
 - Short. Expect a 2 hour experience.
 - Story builds to a climax that feels less than the sum of its parts.

Would Recommend To: Fans of point and click horror games that get right to the point. Horror game fans looking for a good campfire game. People who like the show Stranger Things specifically because it's 80s retro horror/suspense and not because it's a quality show.

Would Alternatively Suggest: The Cat Lady (Same spooky atmosphere and alien backdrop, but with substancially more story for the same price). Her Story (Similar premise, but better payoff at the end, and also cheap).

Thumbing up because I feel it's worth the price, even if I also feel there are better titles out there (see alternate suggestions). Would endorse a purchase if you've played and enjoyed the above already.

So...where to begin.

The cons first. This game, from the top of its logo to the bottom of its soundtrack and atmosphere, is a Stranger Things ripoff. It's in fact so blatant than more than once I couldn't focus past the fact it even exists and hasn't been slapped with a lawsuit or a cease and desist.

That being said, it's also extremely short. And not particularily hard (that is NOT what she said).

It's a small collection of standalone interactive story/puzzle pieces. They are as engaging and interesting as they can be, and a fine enough way to close off a night of gaming. Completing one doesn't take more than 5-10 minutes, and depending on the episode, it might leave you a little rattled of yawning. 

Do I recommend this? Only if you pick it up in a sale.

36178344.review:
The first two chapters were great, they managed to create a creepy atmosphere without relying on jump scares. The first chapter is almost entirely a text adventure and, in my opinion, that was the best part of the game. 

During chapter 3 and 4 you start to notice the developers getting lazy. They didn't have nearly the same polish as chapter 1 and 2. They also introduce tedious mechanics in the last two chapters which feel like cheap padding to push the game over the 2 hour mark so a refund isn't possible. This padding comes in the form of having to decypher code while switching between two screens and dealing with cumbersome controls on the machines you are using. It was frustrating and broke the flow of the game for me.

Storywise the game is alright. The first three chapters tell different stories while the fourth brings them all together and throws a couple twists at you. Nothing world changing but not exactly bad either.

Personally, I regret my purchase even though the game was 66% off at the time. 
If you are interested in the game, only buy it when it is on sale.

36173030.review: I suppose this is another case of not judging a book by its cover.  This game seemed to appeal to me as I grew up in the 80s and love the horror of that time.  However, in my nostalgia, I still enjoy the creature comforts, or better put, the ease of use as delegated by modern software advancements.  I can only recommend this game to a select few, and perhaps only to a select few of said few.  I uninstalled the game after about 20 minutes because not only did I have an anxiety attack brought on by reliving past MSDOS events, but I also felt myself drifting off in the middle of the day.  I'll return to the "select few."  These folks must inherently love, cherish, and adore the text-based adventures of the MSDOS past, and also be able to relive the adventure with the same patience of yesteryear.  I hate to sound like one of the current generation's group of over-diagnosed ADHD kids, but honestly, after living through those times, watching the times change, and embracing some of today's technology I cannot bear to guess the obvious  answer replacing my verbage, then enter another command, and finally enter a location I've already been to and read the same slowly scrolling description as when I first visited it.

36162569.review:
Four different short story adventures that culminate into one wondeful and sad story.

PROS
+ Amazing story (stories)
+ Truly unique gameplay across four adventures
+ Great graphics

CONS
- Short

I didn't know what to expect when I started this game, but it quickly became one of my favorite games I've played in a while!

Four unique and very interesting adventures telling their own unique story, but you'll soon find they are all connected. The adventures offer unique controls from the first text-based adventure to operating a code-breaking system in the third. Great graphics, but the main thing is the wonderful story being told here. So good.

There are a couple of negatives. It is rather short. There was one spot where I got frustrated because I couldn't figure out what they wanted me to type in, but they filled in the blank after a while and I moved on with it. The whole of the game makes up for it. The story being told makes up for it. Highly recommend it!

36147069.review:
Ho giocato Stories Untold pensando di trovarmi di fronte ad un Indie horror di serie B senza troppe pretese e mi sono dovuto ricredere. Mi è piaciuto molto e lo reputo un gioco di grande atmosfera con una storia ben scritta e ben sviluppata. Sono 4 episodi da giocare in sequenza in quanto non si abiliterà il capitolo successivo se prima non si finisce il precedente.  Il gameplay è vario per ogni episodio. Si va da una semplice avventura scritta del primo capitolo, ad usare in sequenza dei macchinari scientifici secondo manuale, inserimento di password e codici secondo un ordine ben preciso e alla ricerca di oggetti per arrivare quindi a svelare i restroscena di questo bellissimo racconto Sci-Fi nel quarto e ultimo capitolo. Una nota importante: il gioco è in lingua inglese e soprattutto nelle fasi in cui ci troveremo a rispondere e dare comandi rispondendo a situazioni tipiche delle vecchie avventure testuali sarà consigliata una certa padronanza dei vocaboli (almeno quelli base: look around, go to, etc...) Nessuno nel gioco vi dirà cosa scrivere e sarete voi a digitare la giusta combinazione di parole in relazione al testo che vi troverete a monitor. Quindi prima di comprare Stories Untold tenete a mente questa cosa altrimenti non riuscirete a proseguire se non leggendo dei walkthrough. Un altro punto importante e è che all'interno dei vari capitoli soprattutto nel secondo ci saranno scene con forti bagliori a intermittenza di luce bianca e immagini molto veloci quindi mi sento di non raccomandare il gioco a chi soffre o è incline a disturbi a causa di questi fattori.
L'audio è strepitoso e anche il parlato in inglese sottotitolato è parte integrante del gioco e ben caratterizzato.  
Si trova spesso in sconto ad un prezzo irrisorio ma lo consiglio pure a prezzo pieno perché sviluppatori con idee così originali secondo me devono essere sempre premiati. 
Durerà circa 2 ore ma saranno ben spese!

36132040.review:

An admirable effort to tell a story in a different manner, let down by two major issues.

1) The user-experience is massively frustrating - slow dials that take forever to get to the correct number, slow text parsers that don't let you correct your mistakes without waiting 10 seconds, and fiddly first-person sections that take you out of the 'feel' of the mystery. It at first builds up the suspense, but after one episode, just ends up being annoying.

2) A final outcome that relies on you making a single incredibly stupid decision ([spoiler]to drunk-drive[/spoiler]), which you're railroaded into. That part completely broke my suspension of disbelief, and took me from interested and sympathetic to simply thinking [spoiler]screw this guy, I have no interest in completing this game and following through his terrible decision[/spoiler]

I'll come back for series 2 (if they do one), but will be checking the reviews.

[h1]Stories Untold[/h1]
Recommended for those are into the screenshots, unique gameplay and uncommon story.

[b]TL;DR version[/b]

    [tr]
        [th]Items (Alphabetically)[/th]
        [th]Score (1-3/3)[/th]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Control and Gameplay[/td]

        [td]1/3[/td]

        [td]3/3[/td]
    [/tr]
     [tr]
        [td]Story[/td]
        [td]1/3[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Value for Full Price[/td]
        [td]2/3[/td]
    [/tr]
[/table]    

[b]LONG VERSION[/b]

1. Control and Gameplay : there are several game modes introduced here, but it's mostly about typing and point-and-drag-and-click type. Different gameplay will later introduced each time. No "timed" action, no need to fear of failing. 

2. Fun Factor : actually the less you know about this game, it's better. I recommend playing it blindly until you got stuck.

3. Graphic : The almost photo- realistic image is great. VERY immersive.

4. Replayability Value : almost zero, since this game offers only one ending. There is no mini- game section for the mini- games, too bad. I bet many people love the mini games they put inside.

5. Sound : the usual BGM for visual novels of this kind. I rarely spot bad BGM on games like this, so I apologize from the lack of sound knowledge. But for effects sounds, etc., I think it's pretty on- point with the situation presented in the game. The voice acting is great too.

6. Story : while it offers different story each chapter, it was too short for my preferences.

7. Value for Full Price : to support the great developers out there, why not? But yaay I get it when it was on sale (again, sorry for supporting full- heartedly but paid half- wallety). I get the bundle version for OST, it's good too. 

8. Others : Play it at night, with headphone plugged in.

36060941.review:
8.5/10

This is, in essence, a text-based adventure game that is not necessarily limited to the text. There are also quite a few point-and-click elements to it, with a sprinkle of walking simulator.

But despite these simple mechanics, Stories Untold is one of the most immersive games that you will find in this genre. It uses the tools given [b]extremely[/b] well, and even the limiting elements of a text-based adventure serve to spicen up the story. The mystery of every episode acculmulate and climax in the final epsode, but the episodes are well-strucutred enough to serve as standalone stories.

The only qualms I have about this game is the text-based system. Although Stories Untold is masterful at using this method, if one is unfamiliar to this kind of game, it takes some time to get used to the system. Even then, I sometimes struggled with trying to phrase things so that the game would "understand." The ambiance of the ending was a bit ruined for me as I struggled for five minutes phrasing my actions.

Still, Stories Untold provides an experience that no other game gives these days. The sheer novelty of its storytelling is captivating. To see if one would enjoy this game, I'd suggest downloading the first episode (I believe its free) and trying it out. If you enjoy it, then you'll enjoy the rest of the game.

36059479.review:
First two chapters: 90. Last two chapters: 40. Overall, I'd give a mixed review if I could.

Stories Untold toys with some very interesting ideas. It has one of the most nerve-wracking yet deeply satisfying sequences I've ever experienced in any horror game. However, one innovation doesn't make a good game. After its early high point, its quality continues to drop significantly. 

The last two chapters feels especially amateurish compared to the first two, with tedious, frustrating mechanics, ugly visuals, and genreally questionable designs.

The game also has frame-pacing issue, with unfixable stuttering throughout. Luckily, it's not perceptible in its best chapter since the camera hardly move in that chapter.

36050963.review:
[b]Enter Bedroom … Read Review … [/b]

If you heard anything about the developers of this game, it might be one of the games that is featured as the first story, The House Abandon. A horror text adventure that took 2016 by storm. A year later, we have an official Steam release with three other stories wrapped in mystery. They may have already made one great game, but can they keep it up for three more?

The House Abandon plays like any other text adventure. Though with a huge difference that might not look that substantial in the beginning. Instead of the screen equating your screen, you are instead seated like you are probably right now, at a desk. The computer actually containing the text adventure off to the left as your lamp shines on your keyboard and the lone photo frame directly in front of you. As you continue on through the seemingly innocent adventure of going back to your home that you moved away from, it quickly turns dark. The house you just went through is a twisted version of itself. And suddenly the text adventure isn’t just a game on the old computer. This might not even be located in an ordinary house as small changes continue to happen right in front of you as the text adventure continues.

The first story is a text adventure, so the other three must be as well right? Nope! The second story, The Lab Conduct, strays away and puts you in the shoes of someone performing experiments on an artifact. With a mysterious voice guiding you to what you need to continue as instructions come into a computer to the left of you. The computer also holding information to help you know which equipment is where and the information about specific equipment. Not having much choice to deviate from the guy that is the owner of the voice as you try to set the needed equipment correctly and turn off unnecessary equipment. The tension ramping up with each experiment.

I might have lied a little. After conducting multiple experiments, you do get back into a text adventure for a short time. Though, do keep in mind that before this, you are made to look into a bright, flashing light to advance multiple times. So if you are susceptible to this, you really should turn away from the game. You do get more story beats that are not entirely clear till you know the full extent of the story.

The next story is The Station Process. Once again, straying away from the previous story's gameplay to show different scenery and focusing more on codes. Stuck in a station placed in a frozen tundra with the only people that are conversing with you are not in the same building anymore. Everyone is isolated in their own station far away enough that going out is risking everything as everyone tries to stay in contact with each other through a radio. Trying to stay alive to not let the other be alone. Though, we can't all have what we want. You have an important role, you receive transmissions and in turn, you send them back. First required to get a passcode, which is attainable by going to the required radio frequency before continuing to send it back.

There is one small hurdle that may hinder you, the microfilm. The microfilm contains the required codes needed to input based on the code word. Little does the game let you to believe, you can zoom into, rotate, and focus so the microfilm can become easier to read. If the code word is “Chevron” after searching for the page titled with it, the lines of code you need to enter is placed here. There might also be values set that needs to be replaced with the corresponding place within the passcode, as it might ask for the second number to replace 'a'. The difficulty ramps up at a good rate, passcodes soon needing a key to decipher and more values coming in. The situation ramping up as we can finally walk away and explore what lies outside. And as you can tell, this chapter holds hints for the overall story, and with the other chapters under your belt, you can easily make some theories on what the next chapter will reveal.

Lastly, the fourth and last story is The Last Session. Where everything comes together and all of the hints from the previous stories are weaved together. The truth finally comes out. Everything coming to a full circle as the game comes to a close. The ending will have a chance of disappointing you. With three stories building it up, it is only normal to think that something big is going to be revealed. And with the overall moral being really overplayed so much that there is a guarantee people will whine in frustration in a room. Though, instead, it does show a different type of horror than it leads you to believe. The type we all fear deep down. I can’t spoil the ending for you, but it can definitely give you mixed feelings on it with how cliché it is.

This would be far from being terrifying if the sound design was horrible. Luckily, this is not the case as the sound design is great. The clank of the keyboard, the whirr of a machine, and a radio tuning in brings up the tension in their respective stories. Bringing life to the world that is subtle, but combined with the story brings fear. Fear of what's to come or the actions you are forced to complete. On this note, the voice work is great as well. Perfectly fitting into the grim world we are given. These voices easy to latch onto, but are they more than we seem? Can we trust them?

[h1]Verdict[/h1]
Stories Untold holds a mix of styles that mess with how the player needs to play. Going from a simple text adventure, to operating machinery, and lastly to entering codes and deciphering passcodes. Giving just enough information that you can get through all parts of the game with few hurdles while also giving out hints that only make sense when you go back and look. Even with the ending possibly being the one thing that can put a sour taste to the rest, everything before is great. Not relying on jumpscares but on the atmosphere as the goosebumps just keeps on coming.

36003266.review:
Stories Untold is an anthology horror game that blends a few genres; namely text adventure, and walking simulator. It is a four part episodic that tells a singular foray into mental health, forgiveness, psychosis and a few other mental tropes. I wish it wasn't! -- more on that later -- But I absolutely adore anthologies. I've seen everything from Hitchcock Presents to Twilight Zone to Tales From the Crypt to reading dozens of written versions, including comics. Digestable, microscopic horror stories is the way that I properly appreciate the genre as a whole (Lovecrafitan short/flash fiction is my standout favorite.)

That out of the way, Untold hit the mark a few times and missed in others. Ultimately given the price, that it can be completed in one setting, and that it can be unremarkably unsettling, I recommend it for the price given.

Pros

*Well written, cohesive narration even if it wasn't to my taste. 
*Chapter 3 astounds as a wonderful little gem of pure, slow burn horror.
*Interface and graphics are surprisingly polished at times, except for walking segments.
*Music is wonderful. Reminds me of Stranger Things.
*Game is at it's best in 2 & 3 when you are controlling puzzles, not writing your moves into a terminal.

Cons

*Walking simulator aspects are almost amazingly bad.
*Low-vocabulary and ridiculously short CYOA elements render them almost pointless.
*Everything is too short, and the overall ending is a lackluster Sanitarium nod.

Chapter 1: The House Abandon

Chapter 1 is the demo to the game, and is also probably the nestegg which created this whole project. You sit down at an ancient little commodore spinoff and play a CYOA text adventure. It is very easy and routine, almost hum-drum, in controls. But the main issue I struck up with was that the vocabulary is so limited. Look around, Leave, etc are very specific. You can't say "Look around me" or "Leave the Car", you need to use "Look Around" and "Exit Car", etc. Besides for this, Abandon does a fantastic job of ramping up the tension as the little adventure continues and has a clever, although predictable, ending.

Chapter 2: The Lab Conduct

In what I originally felt was a playable SCP, I was happy to see so many systems and puzzles at my fingertips. Felt like a controlled surgeon simulator and I was excited to do more than just type. Unfortunately for me, and you, this chapter winds up being as linear as can be. Hell, even the manual is laid out in a way that gives you instructions one at a time in the proper sequence with which you'll be using the tools to fiddle with -- and eventually release -- the artifact therein. I won't spoil the ending, but what happens during the closing act of this Chapter is hairbrained nonsense that felt like a ripoff of a Star Trek concept and was bonkers in execution. Bright lights, loud noises, Shadows of Chernobyl Ending Cutscene style montages, etc. It was disorienting, clumsy, and frustrating and I just wanted it to end.

Chapter 3: The Station Process

Let me get the negatives out of the way, the walking section sucks and going back and forth to the microfilm is frustrating. Two tips; one, you can zoom in and zoom out and adjust focus with the tiny thumb-sliders under the manual. Two, just look up the guide for when it starts beeping at you because you won't be bothered to figure out Morse Code on the spot for a game because it asks you to. 

The tension in this chapter is terrific. The concept is stark and creepy, reminiscent of The Thing to me. You're a radio operator in the arctic and an extinction level event might have begun, and it's up to you to relay codes from your ferry station out to the world that needs it -- be it ships, military, civilians, etc. You can kind of guess and articulate what the codenames, lingo, and frequencies all mean with deduction as the story goes on. It's not a hard nut to crack, but it's a tense one. I just wish a few things were different here. First, a manual would have made more functional sense in a gameworld than the micro film. Some features the MF has aren't utilized, namely slides, and spinning the damn thing is never used and it just irritated me when it did do that via the dial. The walking simulator, and the obvious "scares", were also dumb. This story should have been tripled in length, filled with more lore, had more communication and expanded upon the feeling of impending doom a lot more than the slice it did.

I also would suggest to the developers that right here is an organic time to play with your text adventure. Our mic was cut off, I was happily expecting to be able to type my replies instead to my friends and was wholly let down. 

Chapter 4: The Last Session 

This is an amalgamation of all the previous chapters and isn't quite worth discussing. It's kind of lousy, and my interest dropped off to a point where I just beat it to beat the game. 

-------

My closing comments are this. I am impressed with the atmosphere, delivery of new mechanics, visual polish, wonderful audio and above average writing. From a horror enthusiast, I will tell you this; the game needed more story, a more meaningful exploration of the text adventure system, Chapter 3 could be it's own game, and there is no reason to me why an anthology has to be cohesive. For $10 and about 2 hours of game, you can't go wrong for a bite sized experience this October. I hope to see the devs get enough sales to make Untold 2, where they can properly explore a semi-full game with each mechanic without bleeding into each other. I want to see a long House Abandon, a long SCP style Government Experiment, a grueling and tense story-first narrative of being a radio operator, and let's lose the ending and find a good new forth chapter shall we?

35977891.review:
It's coming up to Halloween so I was digging into my games library for something a bit spooky to get me in the mood. Stories Untold caught my attention and I started to play it – and didn't stop until I had completed it. 

I'm old enough and ugly enough to remember the golden era of text adventures. One of my first ever games was the 1982 BBC Micro release of The Philosopher’s Quest which both hooked me and flummoxed me in equal measures and is, without question, one of the games that turned me into the gamer I am today. (I never did get past the gorgonzola) When I began Stories Untold I gleefully dove into the old habit of ‘using’ ‘pulling’ ‘opening’ and attempting to look at everything even vaguely mentioned in the text and loved every second of it!

This game managed to be nostalgic, clever and original all at the same time, which is a hard balancing act for anyone to accomplish. The puzzles were straight forward and challenging in equal measure, with a couple being downright devilish. Add to that a really atmospheric soundtrack and some excellent voice-acting and you’re on to a winning gaming experience and I would, unreservedly, recommend this game. 

It does, unfortunately, have one (for me rather major) downside. Without giving away spoilers, you spend quite a lot of the game either having a light-source pointed at you or looking into bright lights, which were incredibly uncomfortable. Similarly there were a couple of times you were required to use onscreen manuals that contained the information required to progress and seemed to have no zoom function, other than a slight right-click which made very little difference. Just be warned if you suffer from photo-sensitivity of any sort this may well be hard going. The ability to move the point of view away from the light sources a little more would have been appreciated.

This was a gem of an indie game and I really hope the developers are working on more stuff, because I’ll be right at the head of the queue to lap it up. Stories Untold was great and though I’d consider it more ‘thriller’ than ‘horror’ it was definitely worth the price tag. Nice work!

When I first purchased this game, I was under the impression it was a modern-day text adventure. Instead the game defied expectations, merging a handful of genres to create something greater than the sum of its parts. 

"Stories Untold" is highly atmospheric - almost the kind of game you want to play with headphones on, in the dark, to get the full experience.

There are several layers of storytelling involved in this game, but never to levels that anyone might call "meta." Instead, in a short running time, the game gives you four episodes of well-crafted story with some puzzle-solving, light exploration, and a few easter eggs thrown in.

No Code and Devolver Digital have made something fantastic here, with a wonderful mix of new and old.

35904178.review:
This game is so dedicated to the inane writing cliche eating it from the inside out that an entire fourth of it is dedicated to discarding the uneasy horror tension and parading everything in front of you and asking 'DO YOU GET IT? DO YOU GET IT??? DID YOU SEE WHAT WE DID THERE????'

Yes. Yes I got it. I even saw it coming, but being well-telegraphed doesn't make a lousy writing trope any less bad.

And it's a shame that it wound up this way; I was a fan of The House Abandon and was excited for there to be three more episodes.  There's a lot of incredibly clever game design at work here.  I could have even swallowed the cliche 'twist' if they had more restraint and left it as nothing more than clues and subtext, leaving it for the player to figure out for themselves.

It's not a total loss and I wish that Steam had some sort of middle-ground option when it comes to these reviews.  I'm mad because I was really enjoying the game until it went full bore on explaining itself and fizzling all the atmosphere and intrigue that it had built up.

35898230.review:
[i]Completion State:[/i]
Completed the story (4 hours, 100% Steam achievements)

[i]Comments:[/i]
- Throw back to old text adventures but with a lovely sense of style on top.  Great puzzles and just a really nice set of short story based experiences.  Lovely stuff.  
- Probably my favourite story telling in games.  
- Some comments regarding each individual part are below.  They contain spoilers.
- [i]Part 1 - The House Abandon[/i]
- Very short but quite effective twist on a short coming home story.
- Less obscure than many text adventures of the past with limited commands but this makes it more enjoyable to me, searching for the right verb in these types of game is a pain.
- Love the visual style and it definitely adds something to the game.
- [i]Part 2 - The Lab Conduct[/i]
- More obscure than the previous chapter in terms of solving the lab puzzles but everything you need is in the manual.
- Nice segue back to the first chapters text adventure style.  There is again an additional layer of vagueness here but in this part I think it adds to the atmosphere.  You are after all dealing with what is presented as an [spoiler]alien mind and alien technology[/spoiler].
- Very effective short story telling in this part and nice voice acting.  
- [i]Part 3 - The Station Process[/i]
- Love the puzzle solving in this part.  Using the old microfilm manual is cool, brings back all the annoyances from using these in libraries back in the day!  Also, any game that uses a flow chart in an appendix of a manual as a game play device is alright by me.
- Had to download a tool to hold up to my speakers to solve a particular puzzle in this part but to be fair you could use the instructions/guide in game if you were patient enough, I'm just crap at listening well enough to translate [spoiler]morse code[/spoiler]!  
- Love the final scene in this part, it's very different to the presentation up to this point. [spoiler]Walking back to the hut with a crazy horn blaring whilst getting all sorts of odd dialogue was tense[/spoiler].  Made me leap straight into part 4 mind you.
- Story is gripping and the presentation (including the foley work) is just as stylish as the previous parts and again has some lovely voice acting.  
- [i]Part 4 - The Last Session[/i]
- Takes story telling perspective and turns it on it's head whilst bringing the whole game together.
- I flinched when back in the lab and the [spoiler]view switches to see the drill[/spoiler] and felt internally disgusted when I realised I was [spoiler]the drunk driver[/spoiler] and couldn't do anything to not take [spoiler]Jen home from the party[/spoiler].
- Though the actual final scenes are a little under par the concept and execution more generally more than makes up for it.

35712123.review:
[h1] TL;DR Dredd Without Hats [/h1]

Stories Untold storyline is a little predictable, but the in-game atmosphere is so cleverly crafted that there's an inescapable sense of dread that lasts the entire game. This stems partly from the game's wonderful aesthetic - a twisted 80s world whose underlying themes remind me more of Stephen King's [i] Misery [/i] than Men at Work. It's about time a game did more than just parrot retro tropes.

The Unity Engine works wonders (mostly), with gorgeous textures and lighting. Even set within fairly small spaces, Stories Untold still persuades the player that what they see is only a small part of a larger world. Interaction with the world is limited, but fits well within the scope of the game itself.

The audio is fantastic: the voice actors believable, the click-clacking of keys sublime, and the music a darkened nostalgia. This is a game that deserves headphones and the volume turned up.

Gameplay wise, more polish is needed. The text parser used in some chapters rarely accepts synonyms or similar words, which can become frustrating. I also experienced large stuttering in the final chapter, regardless of quality settings, but this didn't make the game unplayable. The way the player switches between in-game interfaces is clunky; it becomes faster to write things down. Although I suppose in the 80s context of the game, this is certainly more realistic.

The game is episodic, the stories link chronologically. Give the demo a try if you're still unconvinced.

35659641.review:
So, I beat the game in 2.8 hours.  I do not believe this is a good game.  Here's why:

1. Text-based elements are underwhelming.  Sure it's interactive and there are loud noises and flashes at the right moments, based on your input, but you don't have to think about it.  It's very guided.  Efforts to type something different are rarely acknowledged, and you cannot fail.

2. The puzzles are dumbed-down.  Easy-peasy!  It's possibly to see how they can be a challenge for non-technical people, though.

3. Graphical issues are present.  I noticed some boxy shadows occasionally, and the mouse kept escaping from the game window.  Otherwise, the pre-rendered scenes are pretty good.

4. Storyline is pretentious as F.  The numerous disembodied voices reminded me of Dear Esther.  This game has more focus and a conclusion, but is very much more self-referential.

5. Horror aspect is good.  As said before, there are lots of flashing lights/images and loud noises at the right places (this doesn't spoil anything as there is a photosensitivity warning), but the weak storyline lets it down.

Overall rating:

[b]BOO[/b] out of 10

35652338.review: Having grown up with shows like Amazing Stories and The Twilight Zone, it's nice to see a video game tackle that same genre in a way that only games can. Instead of merely making replicating the genre through conventional gameplay and a few twists, Stories Untold reimagines the genre in a way that takes full advantage of what games can do; providing surprise twists in game mechanics just as well and as frequently as the several plot twists across the game's four episodes. All in all, it's great!

35645589.review:
«Stories Untold» es una serie de aventuras conversacionales y laboratorios de tecnología estructurados en 4 capitulos con mecánicas y ambientaciones independientes. Aunque cuenta con un componente interactuable claro a través de sus puzzles, que generalmente se limitan a seguir correctamente unas instrucciones, es evidente que se trata más de una propuesta narrativa que de otra cosa: su duración es la de una película (menos de tres horas) y su interés está en el guión.

Es recomendable, y la impresión que provoca supera con creces su corta duración. Entre sus puntos fuertes, las ambientaciones son sobresalientes. Entre sus principales problemas, que únicamente está en inglés y que la mecánica de aventura conversacional se encuentra excesivamente limitada en cuanto a opciones verbales: si el script del juego pide el verbo "release", seguramente te encuentres durante media hora probando otros mil verbos diferentes: unlock, loose, break, shed, cast off, throw, cut, etc. Aunque esto ocurriese en las aventuras conversacionales originales, hoy en día parece absurdo no abrir el abanico, cuando puede acudirse a librerías de sinónimos en línea: a menudo el jugador sabe lo que debe hacer pero no encuentra la manera de hacerlo tal y como el juego necesita saberlo.

En definitiva, «Stores Untold» una aventura bien escrita, que hila muy fino y que genera mucho desasosiego.

35627696.review:
DR;TL -- No save function combined with steep difficulty tarnish this otherwise beautiful game. If you are a die-hard of this genre, like a good horror story, or don't mind the lack of saves, then get it on discount.

This game is in 4 "episodes", if you play perfectly you could probably finish each in a half-hour. However the learning curve is steep. There is not much hand-holding in this game. Luckily there is a good Steam guide (had to consult at least once per chapter) and also some videos. There are a few hints offered when the game is paused or loading. Pay attention to these an it will save some frustration.

There are a combination of sound, text-parsing and equipment usage puzzles.  A little familiarity with text-parsing games (like Zork and other Infocom games) helps but is not necessary. Again, I had to consult the guide when I knew what to do but couldn't figure out *how* to do it. I enjoyed most of the puzzles, but again felt some were on the hard side. The screen aliasing makes some of the fine details hard to make out - I don't know if thus was deliberate or not to increase the difficulty of some puzzles.

And this is where the lack of save function comes up. The only way to "save" a game is to finish an episode. For most other games I'd just save and do something else when I get stuck. Can't do that here. You can always pause the game and mabe hibernate your computer, but then you can't go to a different Steam game. If the episodes were shorter or easier, I could overlook this. There are several places each episode that could logically be save points. But I think this is enough of an issue that most people should be aware before buying this one that I'm barely down-checking this one, If I could give a neutral recommendation I would,

It's really too bad, since the graphics and voice acting are great, and the story is excellent. It hits many of the classic horror tropes, and does it well. Very few games have this many twists and unexpected turns, and I was on the edge of my seat quite a bit. The game designers put alot of thought into this one. It took me 9 hours to complete (a bunch of it was doing something else while an episode was in progress) and I want to right away re-play the game.

Son zamanlarda oynadığım en orijinal en yaratıcı oyun bu olsa gerek. Text-based adventure'u 3d grafikle harmanlamışlar çok efsane bir senaryoyu da çakmışlar böyle birşey ortaya çıkmış. İndirimden 7 kusür TL'ye aldım. Aslında aldığım zaman o kadar heyecanlandım ki oyunun text-based olduğunu bilmiyordum bile. Hiç bozuntuya vermeden ilk bölümü tamamladım. Sonra ne oldu peki? Diğer bölüme başladım... 

Birçok arkadaş demiş zaten İngilizceniz yoksa tavsiye etmem. Ben de tekrarlamış olayım, sağlam İngilizce istiyor oyun, fakat belli bir seviyedeyseniz upper intermediate benim gibi bilmediğiniz kelimelere oyunda alt+tab yaparak pratik bir şekilde sözlüğe bakabilirsiniz, ki bu da hem oyundan zevk almanıza, senaryoyu anlamanıza ve İngilizcenizin de gelişmesine yardımcı olur. 

Eğer sabırsız biriyseniz biraz zorlu geçebilir ben yarı-sabırlı diye tabir ettiğim kalıba giriyorum herhalde. Oyun içinde 1-2 kere nasıl geçeceğime Tartışmalar bölümünden baktım onlar da zaten en takılınacak yerler imiş. Oyunda takıldığınız yerler olursa "look around" "look at" komutlarını sıkça kullanmaya bakın, zira onlar olmadan biraz zor anlaşılıyor. Bir küçük ipucu daha vereyim, 3. bölümde kağıt kaleminizi hazırlayın yoksa sıkıntı çekersiniz (aklınıza güveniyorsanız orası ayrı).

Uzun lafın kısası, çoğu yerde ağzım açık oynadım (hayır yapay ifadeler değildi) ve gerçekten çok keyif aldım. 8.3 saat ne oynadınız demeyin oyunu alta alıp iş yaptığım da oldu :) Kesinlikle tavsiye ederim. İndirimsiz alırken bile içinizin acımayacağı bir fiyata sahip. Indie oyunları her zaman sevdim sevmeye de devam edeceğim. Bu ve bunun gibi oyunlar hayatımızda güzel izler bırakıyor. Okuyanlara teşekkürler.

35617198.review:
**Spoliers - do not read if you want the full effect of the game**

 [spoiler]
An interesting experiment with storytelling.  The use of 'day in the life' interactions with highly detailed and believable devices /objects is very immersive.  It created a great vibe and nostalgic feeling and added puzzle-like, but organic, gameplay.  It struck me that this would be marvellously suited to an evocative educational situation - such as a museum type 'living' exhibit.  It is genuinely entertaining, mainly because of the level of immersive detail, and I imagine a cold war exhibit done in this way could also be really quite thought provoking.

Beneath the detail each chapter is a fairly short series of linear solutions to puzzles - but the genres are blended in such a way that your actions seem to carry on off the screen.  On occasion it actually does and such confounding of expectation (such as suddenly being able to look/walk around a space) are very effective when taken in context.  That the camera always has things just off view - that there are usually details in the background that may suddenly become the foreground - certainly keeps you guessing as to where the game world stops.and starts.

As a narrative experiment and a development of 'walking simulators' I would say it is a success.  At it's best feeling much more involved than simply being an interloper being shown things.  I certainly engaged with it - to the point where I felt something of genuine agency in the world and felt the pressure and discomfort of my 'character'.  It felt to me similar to audience participation in a drama piece - not sure what is ad-libbed and what is not.  In it's most memorable middle sections it's definitely that sort of playing.

However, this feeling of having direct agency eventually caused a problem as the game progresses.  Your agency in the dreams and fantasies of the protaganist does not synthesise with the eventual fixed narrative of the 'true' events.  I don't know if I wished for the ability to change the past, some sort of Dr Who sentemental logic via timeywimey magic to save the world in a neat bow.  Such a mechanic was in Cryostasis, for example, interesting but not entirely succesful.  In Stories Untold, however, your spirit like presence in the world is ultimately shown to only to have any real place in the protagonists episodes of denial and fantasy, and you live out his exciting intrigues as their subconcious finds ways of avoiding and dening a reality that you have no real part in.  

This reveal is a slightly tedious and forced acting out too - by a mechanism no cleverer than simply withholding all other options.  Regardless of completing these actions in order to progress the section and move the game forward, I did not feel complicit.  I became more aware that I was frustrated by having to do what my stupid character had done - when I would have chosen to do differently.

The feeling of intrigue and dilema that I had felt earlier slowly evaporated as I disinvested.  This feeling could be seen as part of the psychological journey, with me experiencing the frustration of being made to face reality, moving past the earlier inventive attempts at delusion.  The point being - we must thow out the fallacy of attempts to 'solve' the painful memories as if it were a game if we are to be healthy.

Without a doubt my life within the game was in the fantasy and I was therefore reduced and removed, jettisoned with all the other fantastical elements, during the end sequences while the character recieves their just deserts and reclaimed an unhappy place in their world.  Just deserts that, ultimately, seemed nothing to do with me.  [/spoiler]

It is therefore overall a flat feeling I'm left with, a harsh smack of 'Casualty/The Bill/London's Burning' grade melodrama (British low quality TV shows) to knock the inventive escapism out of me like I've been naughty..  Sort of miserable at the level of getting home and finding the internet is down for a bit so no escapism for you, maybe kicking an imaginary puppy - oh you devil you, and then hearing that a great-great-aunt you thought was dead ages ago has actually died but you don't need to go to the funeral or anything so no biggie but you are aware that you are supposed to feel sad so you feel oddly morbid about it..  

Nevertheless - interesting.

35604726.review:
This atmospheric horror game gets so much mileage out of its simple mechanics, and in 3 short hours tells a story that is engrossing, disturbing, and eventually even moving. You really have to play it to believe it. The individual episodes give you elements of horror, sci-fi, and survival  genres, but ultimately this is a game of escalating psychological tension, in which you experience the protagonist's feelings of dread, anxiety, guilt, and powerlessness at the horrors unfolding in front you.

At least that's how it works when everything comes together. Stories Untold is presented as an anthology, and as is usually the case, not every entry in the anthology holds up equally well. The second and third episodes felt slow and sometimes frustrating as stand-alones; the second one compensates for this with a memorable scene and story, but the thid one is almost a total miss, combining the most tedious gameplay with the least suspenseful setting. It all pays off in the last episode though. I would have been satisfied if the game ended with a final stand-alone vignette, instead you get an astonishing final act that brings the seemingly unrelated episodes together and reveals the truth about the game's protagonist. 

The music is sublime. The graphics, while rudimentary, still contain their fair share of haunting images. I imagine some players will find the game frustrating or dull, and if you like your horror games full of action and/or gore, this is probably not the game for you. But if you're looking for a smart, scary game that will stick with you after you're done, you should definitely give Stories Untold a try.

35593743.review:
Wow. This one really took me by surprise. I had never even heard of this game until I got it in last month’s Humble Monthly Bundle. It didn’t really look like my type of thing so I didn’t check it out until a few days ago but I have to say it far exceeded my expectations. 
Stories Untold is a compilation of four short games - or “episodes” as the game calls them. The game takes on the aesthetic of an ‘80s anthology show with each “episode” beginning with an opening title and ending with a credit roll. Initially only first episode is available and completing an episode unlocks the next one. The four episodes are apparently unrelated except that they all follow the basic premise of a character sitting and interacting with a computer screen, this mainly means typing commands or clicking on things. 
The gameplay is really nothing special, but the gameplay is not the focus here, the story is. Unfortunately, I can’t really say much about the story without spoiling it. If this looks like something you would enjoy, then don’t read any more reviews, just buy the game. This really is the sort of game where the less you know going in the better.
Now, this game isn’t for everybody. I think it’s the sort of thing you either love or hate. While I highly recommend it to fans of interactive fiction, if you are looking for innovative or challenging gameplay, look elsewhere. 
There are also a few things I didn’t like about it. First, at points it has the classic text-based game problem of “guess what word the developer was thinking of”. This is generally not a major problem but at one point I did have to consult a walkthrough because I knew what to do but wasn’t quite sure what to type to make it happen. The other annoyance is that there is no saving. If you quit the game, you will have to restart the current episode from the beginning. This is not a huge deal because each episode is fairly short - just over half an hour each - but it is something to be aware of.

35589687.review:
***SPOILER-FREE REVIEW***

This is a short interactive story (I beat it in 3 hours and I'm slow as hell) divided in 4 episodes.

The presentation, atmosphere, and soundtrack are great! You really get in the mood while playing it, especially in the first and last episodes. I highly recommend playing it in the dark, alone, and with headphones.

The story itself is nice-ish. Nothing mid-blowing, but I liked it.

Now about gameplay: almost half the game is played as a text-based adventure game from the 80s. It's super simple and there isn't a lot to do, or choices to make (the game is strictly linear). In the other half, you have to perform some tasks which remind me of "Keep Talking and Nobody Explodes", but with no time limit nor punishment for mistakes (so zero pressure). Because there is no difficulty, these tasks feel more like chores than challenges, and sometimes are simply annoying: game tells you what to do and you do it. Some other (shorter) parts are like a first person....walker? These parts are there exclusively for the sake of the atmosphere, and add little to nothing gameplay-wise.

Bottomline: this is a short story, told in an inventive and atmospheric way. The little gameplay that is present is unremarkable at best.

I'm recommending it because it's a nice way to spend a rainy evening, spending little money (I bought it for less than US$ 2.00, so there's that).

35589598.review:
---SPOILER FREE!-----

This is a game you do NOT want to spoil, so pick through the reviews carefully.
The narrative of this game was excellent and it comes together brilliantly in the end.  It is tantalizing and mysterious, and it never lost my attention.  There is no tutorial, so you might get stuck at bit while learning the commands and inner workings of the game play.  If you get too lost, there are some excellent guides to turn to, so don't get discouraged.  I cannot say more about the actual game without ruining it for you, but know that this is an experience worth having.

There is one con to mention.  The game is separated into parts and once a part is started, you have to finish playing through the whole thing or start it over again.  There is no save function during gameplay.  This factor was really annoying to me, but since the parts are roughly an hour long each, it's forgivable.  Do not let this con turn you off from Stories Untold, just make sure you play the game when you have ample time to complete each section.

Now buy it and enjoy the hell out of it.

35585087.review:
this game is a text based horror puzzle - it is an excellent homage to classics like Red Door - 
without giving anything away i found this game to have me thinking laterally - using my senses of sight and sound as well as using good old pen and paper taking the game beyond the screen as you scramble to write down codes for the codes you are trying to crack - as well as being a homage to old text based adventure games it also pays homage to many of the wondrous technologies of the 1980s and before like morse code, casette players, VHS recorders and microfiche viewers -
anyway the game utilises point and click with text based problem solving and experimentation processes to create a story told in 4 parts - and so far it is a fantastically creepy horror story - really really good - 
superb quality game - using minimal assets but everything done to a high quality to suck you in for a few hours 
the first part is a little lack lustre although does well in setting the creepy tone
the second and third parts really really suck you in
