35583821.review:
This is almost worth buying for the first chapter alone. Almost.

The team that made this clearly has the talent to create something amazing, and there are hints throughout at the potential that Stories Untold has, but it fails to achieve it at almost every juncture. 

The House Abandon is excellent. While sometimes a little restrictive on commands and interactions, and it could certainly use a wider vocabulary, it is engaging, immersive, atmospheric, and full of delightfully morbid surprises. I was hooked, and eager for more. More never came.

The remaining 3 chapters have some interesting elements, but essentially remove any element of interaction, replacing it with commands that must be performed. This isnt so bad or noticable in chapter 2, since they are relatively simple, and the atmosphere draws you in.

Chapter 3 is a mess. The gameplay is cross referencing, syntax checking and data entry. There's enough going on seperate to that to at least keep me interested, or at least willing to put up with the tedium to see what was next. What was next was (spoiler alert) it was all a dream, along with a bog standard, unity default first person section with appaling FOV, and some really poorly sculpted terrain. The interface was not updated here, leaving me with a mouse cursor

Chapter 4 is like a compilation of the worst parts of all of the previous episodes. You're essentially told the ending immediately, and the rest is just going through the motions. The worst offender is the revisit of the text adventure from chapter 1, where in most situations there is only one, very specific command you can type at each step, made more difficult to decipher due to the fact that no consistant commands have been established. Your presense is a formality, and stumbling to the conclusion is a very tedious exercise, killing what little tension and atmosphere there was to an increasing cliche story. 

Despite the amazing potential, I simply cannot reccomend it.

35583567.review:
A psychological horror story is common in the horror video game genre, however I have to argue that this game is set apart from the rest. This game is more story heavy rather than the typical run and hide games. It gives a Twilight Zone vibe that always has a lesson learned at the end and is the culmination of the whole story. 

I personally love the game and absolutely did not expect all four stories to connect. I honestly bought the game, expecting to put it in the backburner while I finished Evil Within, but I was hooked. Yes, the game was a challenge to progress through due to lack of knowledge of text-based adventures, but it paid off. The whole game is an experience worth trying (some hit and miss). 

I would be thrilled if more "episodes/stories" were made in this style.

35583409.review:
A wonderful calling card for the people who made it.
[No Spoilers]

Let me start off by stating that I've completed 3 out of 4 episodes.

Each episode takes roughly 20 mins-half an hour. Yes you are looking at under two hours play time for the entire 'game'. This one of those purchases that it is difficult to give a definite 'thumbs up' or 'thumbs down' for, as what it does, it does really well, but it would hard pressed to call this a 'game'.

Each episode is very different in flavour, but with the same core mechanic: that is you primarilary interact with the story by typing commands into a terminal, flavoured visually in some way with some 80's tech styling, and in later chapters you interact in more creative ways with this old technology. This is where they have done a great job: the attention to detail, visually and audibly, everything looks, feels and sounds, at least like a nostalgic and simplified, analogue reproduction of an era gone past. Here, however is where it differs from the 80's text based adventures it is based on - whereas a 'Level 9' text adventure might keep you entertained for weeks, Each Episode here will keep you entertained while your dinner is in the oven. They have a couple of gimmicks that might make you feel like you've experienced something unique, I won't spoil what they are, but suffice it to say, the terminal in which you type is in it's own 3D world itself, and each episode kind of explores the possibilities of where that could lead.

And here is the problem of this game: it feels like a 'please hire us' concept demo. It's the kind of thing that you might see at a trade show or a 10 minute 'immersive experience' you might see at a science museum. There is no doubting that a huge amount of detail has been lavished on to these 10 minutes per chapter, from the graphics to the voice acting to the sound design, but really when the self-aggrandising, overly drawn out credits roll down after each frisson, you can't help wondering if the entire thing has just been a cyncial attempt to land them all a job in designing, you know, an actual game.

There will be doubtless many other hyperbolic reviews extolling how life changing this game is - it's not, but it does have a very impressive, but brief, perspective shifting gimmick - reviews I feel are more a product of our collaborative yearning for the computer game to come in to it's own as a medium, say compared to the film, the play or the novel; a cause I am rooting for as much as the next man, but come on, I demand more playtime for my money at this price (any price for sub 2 hours gameplay for that matter), clever gimmick or not, and hey, every other medium has been experimenting with these sorts of narrative shifts for years. 

And putting the same name, several times in the same credits is plain old narcissistic.

Graphics 10/10
Sound 10/10
Voice Acting 9/10
Immersion 10/10
Gimmicks 10/10
Gameplay 6/10 (I didn't touch on this but there is A LOT of repetition)
Replayability 1/10
Value for Money 2/10
Likelyhood of Developers landing great jobs and going on to do great things in actual games 10/10

BUY/DON'T BUY = If you love seeing creative exploration of the genre and love indie games, and want it for the library, DENIFITE BUY; If you want a game to get your money's worth from and kill some time, AVOID

35574358.review:
何を書いてもネタバレになるタイプの作品ですので、最小限のレビューになります。

全編テキストアドベンチャーだと思っていたのですが、テキストを含めた「コンピュータへの入力」を題材にした全4章のオムニバスパズル/ホラーと言った方が相応しいかもしれません。とはいえこれはこれで、実写と見紛う真に迫ったどこか仄暗い80年台の映像世界、すぐそばで鳴っているような生々しいサウンドによって、息詰まる数時間を過ごさせてくれました。便宜上"パズル"と呼びはしますが、使われ方が非常に巧みで、いかにもなパズルで没入感を損なわれることは無かったです。
なお英語の分量はそれほどでもなく、あまり難解な表現もありませんが、読んでおかないと進行に厳しいものはある感じでしょうか。

色々なレビューでも絶賛されていますがストーリー構成が素晴らしく、途中「あぁ、これはありがちな話かな？」と少々テンションが下がりかけたところから、見事な展開に思いきり惹き込まれてしまいました。古臭いコンピュータが目の前に置かれただけのシーンでどのような物語が行われるのか、興味を持ってしまった方は是非最後までプレイしてみて下さい。ホラーにしろストーリーにしろ、私の感想は一言で表すと（良い意味で）「ずるい」作品でした。

35573038.review:
Un vrai ovni ce stories untold. Mais ovni veut-il dire mauvais ou seulement réservé aux hipsters ayant déjà un master en arts audiovisuels ? 
      Au contraire : le jeu est un vrai chef d'oeuvre tant part son ambiance que part son gameplay très spécial. En effet parlons tout d'abord de l'ambiance. Elle est avant tout réservée aux fans de films d'horreurs des années 80  -coucou l'inspiration bande son  made in carpenter ( oui certains diront que ça pompe stranger things mais rappelons que ce dernier à les mêmes inspirations ). Cependant si vous n'êtes pas un grand fan du genre horrofique l'histoire suffira à vous donner envie de faire le jeu car elle digne d'un bon M. Night Shyamalan ( une histoire de qualité qui demande de faire le jeu une deuxième fois pour saisir tous les doubles sens ). 
      Ensuite parlons du gameplay, véritable puissance et faiblesse de ce jeu. C'est vrai qu'au premier abord on peut trouver que  le fait de devoir juste écrire ce que doit faire notre personnage n'est pas des plus jouissif mais lorsqu'on rentre dans l'ambiance on comprend pourquoi le gameplay est ainsi fait. En plus, la phase que tout le monde semble retenir n'est en fait qu'un quart du jeu à peine et n'est pas selon moi la plus prenante car malgré le fait que ce soit une entrée en matière forte les développeurs ont trouvé le moyens de faire évoluer le gameplay avec l'histoire, chose très appréciable et demandant au joueur de penser différemment dans sa manière de jouer. Cependant comme dit plus haut, le gameplay peut être perçu comme un défaut car il ne plaît pas à tout le monde et le fait que le jeu soit entièrement en anglais le place très difficilement dans la catégorie tout publique car il ne faut pas juste savoir lire un peu d'anglais, il faut réellement maîtriser la langue et savoir composer des réponses cohérentes ( car expérience perso : je dévérouille une porte et une fois la porte dévérouillée je veux rentrer donc je demande au jeu de faire rentrer mon perso dans la pièce mais ce dernier se trouvant toujours dans le hall le jeu ne comprend pas et me dit alors qu'il ne sait pas dans quelle pièce je veux rentrer et c'est là que j'ai compris que dans la partie texte il faut raisonner comme si l'on écrivait un livre et donc tout préciser ). 
   Ainsi stories untold est malheureusement un jeu à ne pas placer entre toutes les mains mais cela n'est dû qu'à une barrière linguistique donc un conseil pour les bilingues foncez sur ce jeu et si vous ne voulez pas l'acheter faites la démo ( ce que j'ai fait et qui m'a décidé à acheter le jeu)  et écrivez à votre tour un commentaire pour que ce jeu qui est passé inaperçu en France lors de sa sortie aie enfin la gloire qu'il mérite !

35572424.review:
So ... jetzt fange ich die Review zum dritten Mal an da ich nicht weiß wie ich die Review ansprechend schreiben soll bei einem solch aussergewöhnlichem Spiel.

Es handelt sich hier um ein klassisches Text-Adventure mit einer durchaus grusseligen Atmosphäre und einigen Horror-Elementen. Wie diese aussehen und was man zu erwarten hat lasse ich hier aber außen vor - wie das Spiel sich selbst beschreibt: "ein interaktives Horror-Text-Adventure"

Wie gesagt, die Atmosphäre ist zu jedem Zeitpunkt sehr gut, das selbe gilt für Soundkulisse und Musik. Die Grafik wirkt ansprechend und passend zum Stil des Spiels. Der Umfang liegt bei ca. 3-4 Stunden - ggf. etwas mehr oder weniger je nach eigenem Skill.

Da ich nichts weiter spoilern und deshalb nicht so viele Infos geben kann, möchte ich abschließend sagen, dass es für mich eine sehr interessante Spielerfahrung war die ich so tatsächlich nicht erwartet hätte.

Absolute Empfehlung deshalb von mir!


Pro:
- 80's oldschool Soundtrack
- stimmig Grafik
- atmosphärische Soundkulisse
- klasse Story und generell gutes Storytelling
- Spiel bietet deutlich mehr als man zunächst meinen würde
- DEMO verfügbar auf STEAM

Contra:
- an manchen Stellen wirklich extrem kniffelige Rätsel (dessen Lösung das Spiel aber immer bereitstellt)
- gute englisch Kenntnisse notwendig (kein Problem aus meiner Sicht aber für manch einen Spieler vielleicht)
- Umfang nur ca. 3-4 Stunden - diese aber sehr intensiv

-----

35570930.review:
I loved the first two chapters of this game. I thought they were awesome, and I sat down eager to complete the third chapter. Unfortunately this is where the game fell apart for me. The first issue I had was with the morse code section. The code played way too quickly for me and I couldn't differentiate between the dots and dashes. I ended up checking the forum for the solution. Then, for the other segments the clarity of the speaker is not great. It is hard to tell the difference between the person saying 13 and 30. Mike and Like. And the codes being spoken were hard to understand too. Even though I had subtitles selected on the options screen, there were no subtitles for when the code being spoken. I also found the microfiche hard to navigate. I could see there was a zoom in and out, a rotate and a blur adjustment, but I was unable to move the screen up and down and keep the information I wanted on the screen. Parts kept getting cut off and in the end I just felt so frustrated with it, that I gave up. 

I want to recommend this game. I enjoyed the first two chapters, and I am sure many others will too. But if you have any kind of visual or hearing impairment, then Chapter 3 might cause some frustration. And Chapter 4 is locked until Chapter 3 is complete. So disappointingly, I am giving the game the thumbs down.

35569611.review:
Stories Untold is an episodic thriller series of 4 games that feel like separate, interesting adventures which then foreshadow and overlap at the conclusion. There are moments of revelation and connectivity on multiple levels that surprise and draw you in. Even though it is presented as a text-based adventure it also contains many different elements of problem solving and gameplay that become more complex the more you progress. It is not very difficult and is constantly changing its elements which makes it fun to pass the time and is perfect for those looking to solve a mystery.

It has a nostalgic atmosphere which reminds me of the Twilight Zone and old text-based adventure games with a modern approach.  It is worth the cost and my only regret is that I cannot play it for the first time again.

35569492.review:
So. Nun habe auch ich das Spiel geschafft und werde nun mal meine Erfahrungen berichten. 
---
Als langjähriger PC-Spieler sind mit Textadventures ja nicht fremd. Aber es ist doch eine ganze Weile her, seitdem ich das letzte Mal so etwas vor Augen hatte. Und musste ich mich erst mal daran gewöhnen, dass der (virtuelle) PC vor mir auf eine Eingabe wartet. Doch auf welche?
---
So hangelte ich mich intuitiv durch die imaginäre Umgebung und kam ganz gut zurecht, da nicht hundertprozentigen Wert auf eine korrekte Syntax gelegt wird. "go to location" wird genau so akzeptiert, wie das kurze "go location". Und im Zweifelsfall hilft ein schnelles "look around", um sich noch mal einen Überblick zu verschaffen. 
So liest man sich intensiv in die Geschichte ein und "interagiert" in der Spielwelt und merkt irgendwann, dass auch die reale (virtuelle) Welt davon beeinflusst zu werden scheint.....
---
....und an dieser Stelle werde ich inhaltlich nichts mehr preisgeben, denn das Spiel funktioniert nämlich am besten, wenn man nicht weiß, was auf einen zukommt und vor allem der "Hä?"-Faktor, was die weiteren Episoden betrifft, ist ein wesentliches Element, das die Atmosphäre trägt und den "Aha"-Effekt am Ende auslöst. 
---
Die weiteren Epsioden werden der Reihe nach freigespielt und sie unterscheiden sich jewels in der Spielweise. Es ist hier weniger mit Intuition zu lösen, sondern eher durch erhöhte Aufmerksamkeit, etwas Interpretation und einem Quäntchen Logik. Was alles soll und wie sich alles verbindet, klärt die finale Episode. Hier ist man wieder mehr am Probieren, bis man sich durchgehangelt hat. Einen qualitativen Abfall zwischen den Episoden konnte ich nicht ausmachen, aber das ist Geschmackssache. Jede ist eben einen Tick anders und das ist gut so. 
--- 
Technik: das Spiel ist visuell puristisch, spielt in einer stark eingeschränkten Umgebung und setzt voll auf Stimmung. Diese wird vor allem mit der Soundkulisse erzeugt. Passend zum jeweiligen Thema der Episode gibt es die entsprechenden Hintergrund- und Umgebungsgeräusche. Das Highlight hier ist aber der Soundtrack. Mich hat dieses ungute Gefühl, das wie eine dunkle Wolke über dem Spiel hängt und das zu großen Teilen von der Musik ausgeht, sofort an einen Film von David Lynch erinnert. 
---
Kritik: das Spiel ist jetzt nicht ultra-schwierig. Die Zeitfresser sind hier eigentlich nur Falscheingaben, weil man entweder nicht genau genug gelesen oder eben doch mal falsche Befehle verwendet hat und vielleicht auch mal etwas raten muss. 
Das Spiel ist auf Englisch und da es textbasiert ist und hier und da auch Gehör erfordert, sollte man hier einigermaén sattelfest sein. Schulenglisch der Oberstufe sollte aber ausreichen und wer "im Kontext" verstehen kann, kommt auch schon sehr weit. Aber es ist sicher eine Hürde, die das Spiel auch anstrengender macht, als es eine deutsche Version tun würde.
Die Geschichte an sich ist toll erzählt und mit Episode 4 dann auch schlüssig. Die finale Auflösung wird langsam und stückweise aufgebaut, wodurch am Ende kein überraschender Knalleffekt mehr entsteht. Es ergibt sich eben nach und nach das Gesamtbild. Für mich eigentlich kein echter Kritikpunkt, da die Geschichte super erzählt ist.
Allerdings ist der Wiederspielwert etwas mau, denn wenn man den Ablauf kennt, ist dieser eben stets derselbe. Ein paar vrsteckte Steam-Errungenschaften sind vielleicht noch ein kleiner Anreiz, aber das war es auch schon. 
---
Fazit: ein kleines, kurzes und kurzweiliges Spiel, das des Englischen mächtige Spieler in maximal 4 Stunden durch haben dürften und das am Ende eine runde Geschichte ergibt und durch eine fantastische Atmosphäre besticht. 
Es reiht sich in die Liste der "Ausnahmespiele" ein, zu denen ich jüngst "Tha Vanishing of Ethan Carter" zähle, ohne jeodch das Konzept zu kopieren, sondern eine ganz eigene Mechanik aufzubauen.
Wer atmosphärisdchen Midnfuck mag, wird hier fündig, sofern er die Voraussetzungen mitbringt. Der Preis geht in Ordnung und im Rahmen eines Sonderangebots sowieso.

35563096.review:
打折入了试试，评分好像蛮高的。

通关撒花，故事设计精巧。玩法也就是输入go to、look at 、use等这些文本指令完成探索，后面就是按照手册或指令办事，第三章考考听力这样子。
文字的描述玩家自然要发挥想象力，所以代入感就有了。缺点就是流程短了点，3个小时左右通关全成就了。

以下剧透：

[spoiler]原来是一个精神错乱的病人的幻想经历，前三章挖坑，第四章很好的都填上了。
第一章的恐怖气氛，做的不错，游戏中的游戏，引发悬念。主角的Futoro 128k电脑其实是病人在医院看到的一本杂志名字，而电脑显示器就是他病房的电视，玩到第四章就知道了，精神病人现实世界在里世界里的投射。

第二章做的实验，是抢救的隐喻，看到文本描述和那些画面，刚开始我以为是科幻故事，但第四章了解到其实有些是病人混乱的记忆，用象征的方式带进来。

第三章那段是与世隔绝后的james，完全封闭自己，通过数字密码跟外界沟通，电台的指令里面包含了许多线索，比如说“牺牲”题头的指令，point的变量是亚历山大，第四章知道亚历山大是他的心理医生。而第四章的指令更直接，输入指令是致命事故、空威士忌、失控等字样。

第四章把所有线索搞清楚了，但我觉得这不完全是jame的错，明知道他喝了一瓶威士忌，他姐还要他开车，这也许是医生需要他清醒过来的原因，让他明白问题的所在，当然在于他本人当然是把错误都放到自己身上，他的名字：jame aition 这个aition词很奇怪，（感谢echound的校正）翻了下游戏讨论，看到也有人问这个问题，而游戏开发者给出了一个greek词语解释的页面，希腊语aitia包含了错误的、导致等含义，也许也是暗示了这个人因为巨大的内疚出现精神问题。
[/spoiler]

充满悬念的故事引人入胜，英文难度不深，稍微有点阅读能力就能玩，就是流程也太短了，不过通关后在脑子里会想起很多前后呼应的细节，总体来说，是一段不错的体验，建议打折入。

35560833.review:
Stories Untold was recommended to me by a fellow lover of Indie 'experiential' games.   It didn't take me long to play through it. maybe 4h or 5h, including going back to get some extra achievements I'd missed... All in all, I'd say it was excellently executed!

So, the game plays like a four-part miniseries.  Each 'episode' starts with a wonderfully professional intro, and is self-contained, although the later episodes do refer back in certain ways. The episodes feel like a 1970s / 1980s B-rated horror series that you'd find on a lesser-watched channel at 1am on a thursday night... 

Each of the episodes involves interacting with a screen, to solve problems, perform actions and so on.  It has a similar feel in some ways to "Please don't touch" or "Keep Talking and Nobody Explodes"...  A series of buttons, knobs, wires and so forth that you have to manipulate in a certain order...    However, unlike those two other games, this one has some fascinating effects and a bizarre storyline which comes together at the end.

I don't want to talk about the specific contents of each episode, because each one is wonderful, and a brilliant surprise each time.  They're all subtly different but like "KTaNE", the things you have to do build up as the game plays, so you start off typing on a computer, and the last episode has a mix of FPS, some typing and some button-pressing.   

The voice overs, sounds, and visuals are all superb!  The atmosphere projected in the first few episodes had my heart racing.   The third and fourth episodes are just wonderful, with brilliant production values.  Switching between gzmeplay modes is really well done, and the FPS sections are wonderfully balanced against the point-and-click sections.

The game holds together briliantly, and really works for an alternative 'experience' game.      It does require you to use your brain, and there are one or two bits where you have to really puzzle out what you have to do next.  Unfortuntely there are a few little niggles whereby you need to figure out how the game works, before you can figure out what you have to do... And it's easy to miss a small button, or a blurry object, or not know you have to type a certain thing at a certain time.    By and large, though, it's relatively straightforward.

A brilliant game, I really enjoyed every minute of it.  Well worth the money.

35560788.review: Stories Untold has become one of my favourite narrative games, it's atmosphere makes you conscious about not only your in game surroundings but your real life surroundings. The story it tells isn't overly clear to begin with but that only adds to the drive to press on for the answers waiting for you further on. The only negative thing I can really say about this game is that some people might not have the patience for certain chapters and many will probably resort to using a guide or online walkthrough, although there are still plenty of people that enjoy that level of difficulty.

35559343.review:
[h1]Una carta de amor a los juegos de aventura en modo texto![/h1]
Si les gustaba jugar [u]aventuras de texto[/u] allá por los años 80´s, les recomiendo que prueben este juego

La historia está dividida en 4 capítulos, a través de los cuales nos vamos enterando sobre la vida de nuestro protagonista y su familia. La mayor parte del juego se juega escribiendo acciones, tales como [b]"open door"[/b], [b]"go to the kitchen"[/b], etc. En otras escenas debemos interactuar con objetos en la vista de primera persona


[u]Positivos:[/u]
+ Hermosos gráficos potenciados por Unity engine
+ El storytelling es realmente muy interesante
+ La música tiene un estilo similar al de la serie de TV [b]Stranger Things[/b]
+ Los efectos de sonido y la iluminación juegan excelente papel en el storytelling
+ Hay algunos momentos donde debemos resolver algunos puzzles, pero nada demasiado complejo
+ Ideal para achievement hunters
+ Se puede descargar una demo!

[u]Negativos:[/u]
- El juego completo no dura más de dos horas. Me hubiese gustado que las partes de texto sean mas largas...
- De "terror" no tiene nada, pero sí tiene un buen suspenso tensionante!

[u]Neutrales:[/u]
* El juego está disponible en idioma inglés... para mí no es problema, pero quizás para otra gente sí
* Por momentos el juego utiliza sonidos muy agudos y de alta frecuencia... NO jugarlo con audífonos! :)


Quienes me conocen, saben que al final de mis reviews, suelo agregar otros juegos recomendados... pero en este caso, realmente no se a que otros juegos se pueda asemejar este título. Lo recomiendo comprar en oferta

35558873.review:
Stories Untold é uma série de quatro capítulos de jogos de text adventure.
A série implica que os episódios são histórias antológicas, sem conexão entre elas. As histórias são de terror, incrivelmente bem ambientadas, e com uma apresentação bem original. A aplicação de storytelling utilizando de elementos do "mundo real" fora da tela ajuda muito na ambientação.
A única falha é a existência de momentos onde você fica travado. Esses momentos, onde você tenta vários comandos diferentes, te retiram da ambientação e te deixam frustrado.
Com uma fórmula bem inovadora, Stories Untold é um bom jogo para se ter na biblioteca.

35558115.review:
Very inventive idea, but you have to be able to read some stuff off a display that is deliberately(?) made a bit hard to see. I just couldn't read it and wasn't willing to go through all the steps that would have been necessary to try all the guesses I thought were likely possibilities. I have slightly imperfect vision, but it never stops me from playing any other game and, frankly, I don't think a hawk could see the material I had trouble with any better than I did.

UPDATE (Oct. 8, 2017): I originally reviewed this game with a "no recommendation." Changing that to a "yes," but with some hesitation. It really is an original offering and that's hard to find in gaming these days. After the advice in the comments to the first version of this review, I repurchased the game and was able to move past the stopping point that gave me so much trouble. But it's still a bit where I think some will be frustrated, because it's not at all clear that you can do what solved the problem. The same thing happens again in the fourth chapter. That is, you can get past a tough scene, but the solution involves doing a few things that (in my case) felt kind of random.

For the price (about US$4 when I bought it), I'd say it's well worth it. But, if you get to a point where you feel you can't do something (as opposed to don't know what to do), find a good walkthrough (there are many on youtube.com) and give it a chance. There are ways to do all the things you need to succeed. (I know that's kind of vague, but I don't want to include spoilers. My point is that it seemed to me, a couple of times, that there was no way to know you could even figure out how to do what you needed to do. Most puzzle games at least let you find your options fairly readily, leaving it up to you to sort out what to do with them. This one had a couple of points where even knowing what your options were was--for me--kind of tough.)

35556030.review:
Stories can be told in many different ways. 

I myself, love to read, watch films, listen to audiobooks or even play Dungeons & Dragons. But I have yet to find a medium that immerses me more than a video game can. I still remember how such story driven games like Zelda, Mass Effect, The Last of Us and Shenmue (just to name a few) gripped me so tight that I would refuse to sleep just to experience the next 5 minutes. 

Now, if anyone asks for a great example of how interative media can portray a story, I will for sure add Stories Untold to the list of reccommendations. 

Simply put, Stories Untold was an exceptionally clever narrative that I'm confident I'll never forget (and stylish too, I love the 80s theme). Even those who do not like the idea of a puzzle/text based adventure should at least give this a try. I feel that once this game gets it's hooks into you, youre going for a ride.

If I had to give it a rating,

1986/10

I hope you enjoy.

35555211.review:
To start, if you're looking for more horror than thriller, you're in the wrong boat, jump ship.
This is most accurately defined as a semi-text based thriller adventure in 4 parts.

This game has amazing gameplay and interaction, with each of the episodes setting a different kind of unease into you. Unfortunately the payoff for this unease is very weak. It doesn't ever reach full fear, which is why I am very reluctant to recommend this as a horror title, even as it is one of the best games, mechanically, that I've seen in the Text-Based genre.

I find the story to be lack luster in its conclusion, and each of the episodes to also suffer that fate. In each of them, they had the chance to make it end in some way that had more punch, and yet they didn't. Yet, even this didn't distract from the amazing way this game was put together. If there were more games like this one, I would play them. No Code perfectly integrated Text-Based games into an interactive adventure, and for that, they get a big thumbs up from me.

Overall/TL;DR:
Gameplay +++
Visuals +++
Theme ++
Spooky +
Execution Overall -
Story --

8/10, solid title.

35549686.review:
This Adventure/Horror game might actually be the best game I've ever played. It's genius, perfect and it just drags you in. The interactivity of the stories and puzzles flows so well it's seemless, I felt tense at all the right points and the story went at such a perfect pace and gave twists and turns that put the Original Series' on Netflix to shame! Each episode tells it's own story, but they all link. This isn't a new idea for an interactive story but it's been done so well nobody will ever replicate quality ever again. Without spoiling it, it's hard to expalin how good it actually is, but I love box sets and Netflix original shows and this beats anything I've ever seen before. 

If you're unsure on whether it's for you I'll run down some basics of the game. There are NO jumpscares, just a few loud noises and eratic light changes, personally I'm not a fan of them so I thought I'd clarify for those similarly inclined. The puzzles aren't hard, but you might want something to write notes on. It's not entierly a text and puzzle adventure, it does feature some exploration to show off it's fancy graphics which are really nice. Finally, this isn't very replayable but that shouldn't sway you buying it 

If I could forget and replay one game, I would always say Fallout: NV, Spyro the Dragon, Resident Evil 2. From this point on it is this and I think that this statement really says just how good it is.

Very good game, but many of the commands needed to be typed in are completely obscure (for example, you need to "use" something which hasn't been mentioned and that you have no way of knowing about), and others (such as "look" or "get") don't work when they obviously should. Which is to say that the game has a real 1980's CLI feel, complete with the sense that the commands were created and tested by one single person, a person with a rather odd grasp of English.

The mouse input is a little slow to respond, so sometimes you need to click and hold, not just click. Actually, you need to do that fairly often.

For all that, it is well-done overall and quite fun. More eerie and intriguing than scary.

35545420.review:
This brought back memories of the old commodore 64 and vic20 days of text adventure games.
I had played the free version, the house abandon, a few months before I heard they were doing a full release. As soon as I heard about it I knew I had to try it.
Sure, it's pretty short, but for the price it's well worth it. Not just for the nostalgia it brings, but for the great story it tells, and the way that it manages something I had never experienced in a text adventure; actual tension and even fear.
At one point in the house abandon story, I actually looked over my shoulder when something happened, actually expecting to see someone behind me for a split second there, until I realised the computer I was using was just on the screen.
So clever is the storytelling, and so masterfully woven into the gameplay, it just pulls you in at every level.

At a couple of points in some of the stories, it is not very obvious what you are meant to do and I think that more than a few people have ended up going to walkthrough video's to find out what they are supposed to do.
Even for me, a veteran of the old text adventure games this was emulating, had to scratch my head for a good few minutes sometimes.
But it always felt worth it when I finally figured out what to do.

Have to give this a thumbs up, for all it does. For the nostalgia, for the clever use of gameplay mechanics to make you feel "in" the game, for the really smart storytelling (even if the ending is a bit of a letdown compared to the rest), and for the great way they use different gameplay styles for each chapter, while keeping it in a pretty similar vein.

Really good, really smart, really stylish, thumbs up all round. For the price you can't really go wrong.

35543222.review:
Easily recommended for the price. It is well written, unique and original.

Problems:
-Often the puzzles are too specific, if that makes sense. This was a problem that plagued old text adventure games, where driving somewhere was a single command yet washing your hands consited of three non trivial steps. Similarly it can often happen, that you KNOW what answer it is expecting yet you cant format it correctly for the game to accept it. This is not a challange, this is bad game design.
- Generally the text recognition engine is very stupid. Taking in consideration how short these segments are (compared to an actual text adventure game) , it really could have had some finesse added to it.
- It is not really a game as such, more like an interactive adventure. This isn't really a problem, more like what the game is like
-No replay value.

Still none of this should steer you away from this title, this is a great game with small problems, and great ideas.

Game Informer - “A treasure trove of  “MORBID?” Delights“?  Wtf does that even mean? The f-ucking game isn’t scary….at all. It builds minor suspense, then ends. Nothing f-ucking happens. 35534056.review:
This is one of the few games where I felt had no choice but to sit and finish it in one sitting. I was totally gripped by the intellectually stimulating narrative from start to finish. This is undoubtedly one of the most intelligent and clever horror stories ever told in a video game format. I have a few main points

[b]1. The episodic structure[/b]

While there is an option to unlock all episodes at once, I highly recommend going chronologically. The mystery builds higher and higher with each it iterration, the suspense boiling until it hits a breaking point in epsiode 4. It's just one of those stories that makes you go "Wow." This game left me with a feeling akin to seeing the credits roll after finishing a movie like Memento or Fight Club.

[b]2. The Audio[/b]

[i]Music[/i]

The music in this title is wonderful. The 80's retro synths will make you wish you were driving your DeLorean down a dark deset highway. The soundtrack is very reminiscent of the music in Stranger Things. Ominious, but engaging synths that are straight from an old Yamaha keyboard. The ambient music can also get very spooky at times, with the subdued melancholy piano right behind you at every step.

[i]SFX[/i]

The sound effects in this title are really what makes it so incredible. From the very start I was already noticing that the execution of sound in this game would be what carried the narrative, and my presumption was correct. From every lightning strike, whir of a drill, and tik-tak of a keyboard, I was all ears. While most of the story is based around text, the finer things are buried within the sonics. A faint car crash, the beep of a heartrate monitor, no matter what it is, the title succeeds at making you think it's actually there in the room with you. The use of surround sound adds life and depth to the what would otherwise be a very simple walking simulator. This goes without saying - make sure you use headphones when playing this title.

[b]3. Graphics[/b]

Being on the Unity engine, I wasn't expecting a whole lot in the way of graphics, but I was a little surprised. The textures are very clean, and the use of lighting, especially in epsiode 1, are very visually pleasing.

[b]4. The story as a whole [/b]

The entire story is a very interesting foray into mental health, and the way the perception of reality can be altered based around that. I won't say much here as most of the gratification of this story is figuring things out along with the protag. One thing I will say is that the story is gripping and unlike may I see in games nowadays.

[b]Closing[/b]

I got this on sale for something like $3.50, but I would have gladly paid full price. Devolver Digital is one of my favorite devs/publishers, and No Code deserves nothing but praise for their unique and exciting spin on the horror game.

35533064.review:
[h1][b]First things first... the game starts with a warning for people who suffer from flashing light triggered medical conditions. For a reason. If you suffer from light triggered seizures, or other medical issues, or are sensitive to jarring, loud sounds and bright, flashing, almost painful lights... turn away from the Store page now. I warned you...[/b][/h1]

[b]This game is NOT what I expected it to be.[/b]

[b][u]That is what made it so wonderful for me. [/u][/b]

You will either "get it" and enjoy it, or you won't.
It isn't a blood, guts, and gore, man-with-a-hockey-mask-on-holding-an-axe kid of horror game.
Okay, the blood, sorta guts, and gore is there... just not in the way you might be used to.

This game is a MINDF**K. 

It is a psychological horror, an exploration and discovery game. You might not like some of what you discover. About the characters and perhaps... about yourself. It gives you everything you need to complete it. It will give you hints. But it isn't going to hold you softly in its arms and carry your through. You will have to look around. You will have to think outside of the box, without overthinking things. You will have to deal with some heavy thinking and possibly some heavy introspection.

It isn't what you expect it to be, when it is finally over. That is what it so wonderful for me.

Your Mileage May Vary. Widely.

Tiny spoiler lies ahead... stop scrolling now if you don't want to know...













[h1][b]PSA- Don't Drink And Drive. One day... it will haunt you.[/b][/h1]

35525092.review:
Stories Untold çok farklı bir "deneyim." Eskilerin metin tabanlı macera oyunlarına (Text-adventure) aşinaysanız kendinizi hemen evinizde hissetmeniz olası. Çünkü Stories Untold tıpkı o oyunlar gibi oynanıyor. Klavyeyle ekrana "Open The Door", "Go Upstairs," "Look Around" gibi komutlar giriyor ve çıkan yazıları okuyup hikâyeyi o şekilde takip ediyorsunuz. 

AMAAAAAA...

Stories Untold bu oynanış yapısını görsel efektlerle ve seslerle birleştirmiş. Böyle olunca da çok çabuk kaptırıveriyorsunuz kendinizi atmosfere. Toplamda dört bölüm var ve ilkinde eski bir tüplü televizyonun başında oturmaktan başka bir şey yapmıyormuşuz gibi görünüyor. Derken bir kapı gıcırtısı, ansızın çalan telefon, beklenmedik bir gürültü... diye gidiyor ve bir anda kendinizi ekranın dibine yapışmış buluyorsunuz.

İkinci bölüm bir uzaylı araştırma laboratuvarında geçiyor ve bu kez çevreyle daha çok etkileşime girebiliyoruz. Üçüncüsü kutuplardaki tuhaf bir üste, bir tür kulede geçiyor. En zor ve en uzun bölüm bu. Çünkü mors alfabesi vs gibi bir sürü kod çözmeniz bekleniyor. Allah'tan bir ipucu kitabı var bu bölümde. Tabii onun nasıl kullanıldığını çözmek de başlı başına bir bulmaca sayılır. Son bölümse... o sürpriz olsun. Hikâyeyi tamamına erdirip her şeye açıklık getiriyor çünkü.

Tek eleştirim, sonunun bağlandığı yeri pek sevmedim. Evet, güzel bir mesaj veriyor. Ama ne bileyim... "bu kadar " mantıklı bir açıklaması olmasa, biraz daha fantastik bir şeye bağlansa daha çok sevinirdim :)

Text adventure oyunlarına aşinaysanız ya da yazarak oynamak sizin için sorun değilse (ve İngilizcenize güveniyorsanız) bu farklı deneyimi bir kez yaşayın derim. İlk bölümünü ücretsiz oynayabildiğinizi de ekleyeyim. 7/10

35463424.review:
Relive the nostalgic era of text-based adventures with an interesting first person twist in Stories Untold, a point, click, and type adventure.  Divided into 4 episodes, your adventure takes place across a series of seemingly unrelated environments that all eventually tie together in the finale.

Similar to Zork or early Sierra adventure games, Stories Untold requires a familiarity with classic text parser style input. Rather than moving from room to room or clicking on objects, you sit stationary in front of a screen and type in commands such as “look around” or “use key in door”. Later episodes combine various puzzles with manual text input and some of them can be quite challenging. 

I’d have a lot to write on the story (which in my opinion was very well done) but it’s hard to talk about it without spoiling the whole thing. I will point out though that a full playthrough of this game is likely to run you 2-3 hours at the very most so budget accordingly for your time.

35387136.review:
When you break horror games down, they tend to fit into a few convenient categories. Sometimes there are real monsters to fear, sometimes you end up in their domain, sometimes you're struggling to stop them from running amok, and sometimes they're all in your head. I'm not going to spoil Stories Untold by indicating which road it travels, but I have to be honest that it's my least favorite one. And if it didn't do everything else so very, very well that might be a dealbreaker for me. Luckily, it still manages to be exceptional in every way except its story. Ironic, isn't it?

Stories Untold is a collection of four horror-themed vignettes built around interacting with old 1980s-era technology. The first, The House Abandon, is an old 80s-style text adventure played on an ancient, boxy computer. The second is set in a science lab with plenty of clicky, chunky audio/visual equipment to play with. The third is at a polar listening station where you must transmit coded radio messages. And the fourth vignette ties it all together very effectively. Each one works a creeping unease into your activities in different and clever ways, often by toying with your perspective as you mess with antiquated interfaces.

The real hook of Stories Untold is how you play it. Not content to simply give everything a thick 80s sheen of fake wood paneling and cathode ray tubes, your primary means of interacting with the game is via text parser. Not only that, but the computers you enter your text commands on are distinct entities within the game world. In The House Abandon, for example, you're playing through a text adventure on an old Commodore-style terminal. Instead of just showing the screen, the monitor, keyboard, desk, and seemingly extraneous details like pictures and clocks are all modeled around it.

These elements are not actually extraneous, of course, because the way this game gets you is in how your text parsing adventures affect everything around them. Your commands are obviously going to have different effects between a text adventure, scientific equipment, and code transmitters, but the story also unfolds around you as you go through the motions of your tasks. There are further forms of interaction as well which are used to great effect, and can inspire surprising amounts of dread in how they diverge from your safe typing up to that point.

As effective as the moments are in Stories Unknown, I would be remiss not to clarify that they are inconsistent in their pacing and effectiveness. The House Abandon is an incredibly strong starter and sets the tone for the game perfectly, but the scares trail off a bit from there. The second chapter lost steam for me pretty quickly, and while the third has an excellent buildup, the payoff was weaker than I expected. This is less a function of how the scares are planned and executed and more how they tie into the overall story, which for me detracted from everything that was going on.

Mechanically the game is perfectly sound, and for a text parser I found the term recognition mostly adequate. You're not going to have a ton of options at any point, so the game is mostly figuring out what command you need to enter to proceed. The third chapter in particular has you following a lot of coding instructions that feel like a play on how linear the actual gameplay is. Still, it forms a natural puzzle system where you can divine the next line to enter based on a little experimentation and observation. I only got stuck on one line at the very end of the game, only because the parser wanted me to specify the contents of a bottle instead of the bottle itself. Overly picky, but certainly not a dealbreaker.

The only potential dealbreaker is the story, and I wish I could expand on it for your benefit but it really is best experienced for yourself. That's really where I'd put Stories Untold, as a game that's worth experiencing so long as you're prepared for what may or may not come in the end. As much as I dislike the story I adored the retro aesthetic and the tactile pleasure of hearing keys clicking as I typed into the terminals. Obviously if the story lands in the right spot for you this is an excellent buy, but even if it doesn't this is a fine take on a dormant genre that proves text parsing can still carry a game.



Did you enjoy this review? I certainly hope so, and I certainly hope you'll check out more of them at https://goldplatedgames.com/ or on my [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/audish#curation]curation page[/url]!

35015662.review:
"It is all my fault."

[h1]What it is about[/h1]

Stories Untold is a rather short game of four seemingly independent short stories. There are multiple different gameplay mechanics, that range from text adventure to point & click and to number puzzling. The whole game sets the player into a 80's atmosphere.

[h1]The Pros[/h1]

What I really liked about the game was at first the atmosphere and thrilling feeling it gave you. I have to admit I am not a fan of text adventures, I find it tiring and rather boring. And when the game started with exactly this mechanic, I was not very enthusiastic. But to my surprise it was actually really entertaining and also surprisingly creepy. The text adventures parts have been cut to just the right length, and were implemented very well to the modern gaming feeling. Also I liked that the game uses multiple different gameplay mechanics, that may be all rather simple, but the change of mechanics causes the game to not become boring so fast due to simple gameplay.
The story (stories?) are all really exciting, they can put you in place of the protagonist immediately, and most of the time you have no clue about what is actually going on until you almost completed the short story. I enjoyed this mysteriousness quite a lot. 
Lastly, I feared already when playing the game for a few minutes, that the ending would be open for interpretation, so I tried to gather every little piece of information and turn it around three times to just find a connection that could become relevant in the end. But I have to confess that I was relieved that the game ends with a linear ending, which I think fits better to the game and was the right decision.


[h1]The Cons[/h1]

Although there are multiple different gameplay mechanics, some of them felt tiring nonetheless. It was not the text adventure, just to make this clear, it was really awesome. But the number puzzling was dragging a bit because it was so long, just as well as the point and click part, because you did not have to think almost anything and it did't push the story very much. Additionally, the game is no technical highlight. Graphics look fine on Steam screenshots, but in truth they are very washed, not optimized and very edgy. I think there is some potential for improvement. Other than that, the only thing I can point out as a Con is the playing time. I did not check the clock, but I cannot have been playing much longer than 2 hours. I really enjoyed these 2 hours, but I also wished the game would have lasted for a bit longer, left me a bit longer in the dark and tell me another mysterious story. A fifth episode somewhere in the middle would be a big improvement imho.


[h1]Conclusion[/h1]

An atmospheric and gripping game with refreshing gameplay elements and an exciting story. It drags behind technically, and can become boring at some points, but for a short ride with this one you cannot make much of a mistake. I would give Stories Untold [b]8[/b] out of [b]10[/b] points.

35008456.review:
A small collection of fantastical short stories, with interaction in the form of text parsers, machinery to observe, understand and operate, and other small surprise segments. It's a narrative experience first and foremost, aimed at enthusiasts of the Strange. If you appreciate piecing out together stories from seemingly disjointed bits of information, poking at buttons hoping for the hum of machinery, and don't mind feeling a presence over your shoulder, be sure to check it out!

Recommended for: readers, writers and dreamers, people who enjoy the sound of pressing buttons more than knowing what they do, people who like to follow sets of instructions while unsure if they're opening radio channels, fighting aliens or causing nuclear war

Not recommended for: people who can't type, people who want a long experience, people who want straight answers straight away, people who need adrenaline fueled action to feel alive

35004563.review:
PROS:
+ Interesting premise. Which I won't reveal!
+ Story kept me hooked until I finished all four episodes.

CONS:
- Repetitive puzzles. In the third episode, you basically complete the same puzzle four times in a row. And it wasn't even challenging the first time...
- Often frustrating to figure out exactly what the text-based sections want you to type. I spent close to five minutes trying to figure out one entry, and ended up going online to get past.
- Too short. I finished the game in a few hours. I really wish there was a little more story.
- Not horror? I was excited to see how scary this game would actually turn out to be. And I was disappointed. The first episode was fairly creepy, the second and third weren't scary at all, and the fourth was iffy. I saw the ending coming from about a mile away, so it wasn't satisfying in the least.
- No music. The first episode has SFX only, no music. So I put on some spooky music on YouTube as I was playing. Helped a lot.

CONCLUSION:
This is a great idea for a game, but doesn't pull it off. To be a really good game, it needs more content, more build-up, more tension, better interface, and music. If you want a couple of hours of light spookery, go ahead and try it, but you can probably find something better.

FINAL RATING: 3/7

34963003.review:
Stories Untold is a delightful little suspense game. Very retro in design and execution, it evokes an ’80s aesthetic in everything from the audio and visual design to using a text parser for some of the gameplay. The individual stories are interesting and varied, and are at times really clever. They build on each other, employing things you learn in the first story in the second, and so on. While the first story starts out with an initially intimidating text parser, it was easy and simple to play through, and later stories use more mouse-based interaction.

I enjoyed playing through the individual stories, but it’s the fourth story that really made me think, “Wow, this game is great!” It’s really clever and smartly done, and was an excellent conclusion that elevated the entire game.

I would characterize Stories Untold more as suspense rather than horror, because it builds and instills a feeling of dread throughout rather than utilizing jump scares, or body horror, or being chased by a monster. As someone who doesn’t like horror games (or movies) because they’re too scary, I had no problems playing Stories Untold.

34954859.review:
Понятно, что 80-е снова в моде. Непонятно, почему кроме стилизации и наива в этих сюжетах нет ничего. Они не просто избитые: по уровню прямолинейности им можно тягаться с историями у костра в лагере. Текст написан на уровне школьного сочинения. ("Теперь дом стал заброшенным и старым. Тут неприятно находиться. Вы идете к двери. Дверь грязная, ветхая. Что-то не так. Включаете свет. Он неприятно мигает. Как же здесь отвратительно, вы едва сдерживаетесь, чтобы не убежать. Перед вами коридор, ведущий на кухню, и лестница. Тут неуютно, и находиться в доме не хочется. Дом старый.") Повороты предсказуемы, пока в них есть хоть какой-то смысл. Потом пропадает и он, и вот тогда становится немного страшно за бессмысленно растрачиваемое время. 
Атмосфера хоррора и мистики часто перебивается непроработанной механикой. Второй эпизод состоит из рутинных, повторяемых действий по принципу "бог любит троицу". В первом эпизоде, сидя за ПК, можно писать что угодно после основной текстовой команды. Например, если вы напишите go to the front door and f*** yourself, вам успешно засчитают первую часть команды. Открыв эту маленькую возможность, я сильно попортил финал, ерничая в каждом ответе.
С другой стороны, у Stories Untold не отнять интересную графику. Попытка не просто накидать в кадр артефактов из 80-х, но передать их фактуру, отличная. Музыка вполне соответствует духу игры. Звук не подводит. 
Это любопытный опыт, но, если вы здесь ради самих "историй", будьте готовы к тому, что это средней руки фанфик.

34896371.review:
What would happen if you took the essence Stranger Things, The Twilight Zone, and Chrisptoher Nolan and then put it into a video game? You get Stories Untold, a neat and obscure horror game. All you need to know is that what first started a fairly linear text-based adventure turned into something that made me bust out some notes and kept me at the edge of my seat for it's entire 2 hour length. But, do keep in mind that this game is very linear and is more of an interactive TV show than a traditional game,  It's a one-and-done affair with  little to no replay value. Though replay clearly wasn't what the devs were aiming for.

Finally, this is one of THOSE types of games, the kind that's at their best if you go in knowing as little as possible about each of the 4 episodes.  I did that and it ended up being one of my favorites of 2017.

I started playing this game after reading the positive reviews. Hadn't heard of it before, the name didn't stand out and I wasn't expecting much - I only received it as part of a bundle...
But as soon as I started playing I was gripped.
The game consists of four parts and each one pulls you deeper and deeper.
It's been a long time since a game genuinely made the hairs on the back of my neck stand up, and I loved it for it.
I'm not normally a fan of "horror" games, but I wouldn't class this as one. It's incredibly gripping, very spooky and is an experience not to be missed!

34882392.review:
This is a bit of a mixed bag, and short (expect to finish it in around 2 hours), but I enjoyed playing it.

The game's description of "a compilation tape of four experimental adventures" is fitting. The first episode has a disctinct horror/thriller vibe, which moves into sci-fi for the next couple of episodes, and concludes with a mystery/thriller element. 

It also straddles a few game genres - part text adventure, part walking simulator, part instruction-puzzle - and technically it does none of them terribly well.

Where this game shines is blending everything together. The different game genres are mixed within each episode, and the finale brings together the various story elements in a fitting way.

This game is just Brilliant. I highly recommend it, it was a blast to play.

Performance wise this game runs smooth like butter and I didnt had any trouble with it even on my Ultrawidescreen. The voiceacting is great and the overall sound atmosphere as well.

Game is split in 4 different "mini game" episodes, only letdown was the 3rd one, where you´re supposed to encypher some Morsecode and the Nato Alphabet. I got this game from a friend and didnt knew what to expect from it but it was a pleasant suprise. Only thing I really disliked was the "plot" behind all of it but overall a really great experience. A tad short thoo, finished it in 2,5hours.

Episode Three: Oh I feel a contact/the thing vibe, I like that. And new gameplay. WTF?? I'm lost. 

Episode Four: I need to know. Oh my god.

It's one hell of a story guys. Play till the end, [spoiler] the narrrative is all connected [/spoiler]

34857582.review:

Da ich ohne große Erwartungen an das Game heran gegangen bin, wurde ich mehr als überrascht. Gerade die erste Episode fand ich unfassbar unheimlich und wollte an der einen oder anderen Stelle gar nicht so wirklich weiter spielen...natürlich im guten Sinne (ja, ich bin ein Angsthase ^^).

Ich habe ein bisschen länger als 4 Stunden gespielt, was meiner Meinung nach genau die richtige Länge für dieses Spiel ist.

Von mir gibt es also eine absolute Kaufempfehlung! Holt euch das Game, lehnt euch zurück und genießt (?) einfach diese Atmosphäre. 

(Ich empfehle übrigens das Ganze mit Headset und im Dunklen zu spielen, hätte ich auch gemacht, wenn ich nicht so ein Schisser wäre :) )

34856976.review:
[h1]QUICKIE: [b]STORIES UNTOLD[/b][/h1]

Un' avventura in parte "text-based": interagite con dei computer presenti nei 4 capitoli della storia di questo gioco e "scrivete" gli eventi a cui il/i protagonista/i prende/ono parte (non voglio spoilerare).
Giocando i primi 3 capitoli vi chiederete: "wow, non ho la minima idea di cosa stia succedendo", poi arriverà il 4 capitolo che metterà tutti i pezzi del puzzle insieme e vi farà dire... "ah... ok...".
La parte di gameplay testuale si concentra principalmente nel primo e nel quarto capitolo, mentre negli altri 2 capitoli i puzzle sono resi decisamente più interessanti da alcune meccaniche particolari che richiederanno un po' più di ricerca ed ingegno per essere utilizzate, purtroppo ciò che molti elogiano di questo vg, il gameplay a base di testo scritto, è decisamente a senso unico (e quindi noioso)... ciò che intendo con "a senso unico" è che i comandi scritti da utilizzare per risolvere questi segmenti si contano sulle dita di una mano (3 in effetti "go to x" "look x" e "open x"... in due occasioni ho usato anche "talk to x" e "yes/no") e fanno sembrare questi momenti qualcosa di inutile, ogni evento si svolge in uno ed un solo modo... perchè darmi la possibilità di scegliere quando in realtà non posso fare altro se non quello che vuole il gioco?
Altro punto degno di nota (che non è negativo ne positivo, è semplicemente lo stile del vg) è che per il 90% del gioco non vi muoverete dalla vostra postazione, potrete guardarvi a destra/sinistra (almeno nei capitoli 2/3) per interagire con macchinari fuori dal vostro campo visivo, ma la maggior parte del tempo sarete seduti su una sedia con di fronte uno schermo/dei macchinari con cui interagire, i vostri movimenti finiscono qui.
Insomma, se non si era capito questo gioco non m' ha colpito molto, la storia è decente ma niente di chè e, soprattutto, lineare (nel senso che non c'è alcun modo di cambiarla), i segmenti "text based" sono inutili, non ci vuole molto per capire quale sia il comando da inserire e qualsiasi altra interpretazione della scena che si sta vivendo è inutile, l' unica cosa salva questo vg sono il secondo e terzo capitolo in cui i puzzle sono un po' più (meccanicamente) complessi (nonostante rimangano molto semplici).
Onestamente credo che un gioco come Event0 (che costa 10 euro in più, ma ha anche più rigiocabilità) riesca meglio in tutto ed i segmenti "text based" lasciano molto più spazio al giocatore, dando più scelta nei comandi da dare e risposte più varie da parte dell' ia.

Allora perchè lo consiglio? Perchè andare al cinema oggi costa una decina d' euro e questo gioco può intrattenere per circa 2 ore, con tutti i suoi difetti rimane un vg abbastanza particolare e, per quanto vogliano sempre fare gli edgelord che "non seguono la moda", quelli della Devolver anche con questo titolo si confermano degli ottimi publisher. Se devo essere sincero poi, nonostante tutti i difetti, si vede che i developer si sono impegnati per rendere come si deve la loro "idea" e, almeno a livello visivo e stilistico, ci sono riusciti

[b][i]+è un' esperienza videoludica abbastanza particolare
+il secondo e terzo capitolo hanno dei puzzle che riescono ad essere interessanti
+la storia non è male

+/- il gioco si svolge in prima persona quasi completamente fermi in un punto

-mi aspettavo molto di più dai segmenti solo a base di testo, invece le opzioni per interagire nel "mondo scritto" sono estremamente limitate
-ha una durata di circa 2 ore, senza praticamente alcun motivo per giocarlo una seconda volta
-per chi non conosce l' inglese è un acquisto inutile non essendoci una traduzione italiana ed essendo basato per lo più su comandi scritti[/i]

34846526.review:
Unfortunately, I can't recommend this game, even though I would like to. This game has a great concept (a mostly text based horror game), which initially I enjoyed, as it was a nice change from the horror game norm. This lost its luster for me about 20 minutes into the game however, as typing the same sentence over and over again just to realise I had to word it differently became extremely irritating. This was, like I said, irritating, but manageable. 

This brings me to my next point, which ultimately ruined the game for me: strobes, SUPER high pitch noises intended to 
subconsiously instill fear in the player, and jump scares (this one is less present than the other two but still a pain). These three elements are present in almost all games in the horror genre, and in my opinion these are a cheap way to make your game scarier. Again, these three things, when used in small amounts, are manageable, but in this game, which is supposed to be a mostly text-based game, they are cranked up to 11. This gets really bad during one point in the second episode. I'll try not to spoil anything, but towards the end there is a puzzle that requires you to stare into a light while also typing something on your console. If you are like me, and didn't get it right away, this can turn into a solid 20 mins of staring into a strobing light while barely audible infrasouds scream at you. Long story short, by the end of this puzzle, you WILL have a migraine, and black spots in your vision (that is, only if you don't get a seizure). 

This leaves you with the option of course to turn your sound off on your computer (which I did). Doing this however, leaves you without any audio cues, and honestly makes the game kind of boring, as it leaves you with a story you can play very slowly (eliminating all "spookiness"), and strobe lights.

All in all, this is a very short semi text-based horror game that relies too much on horror game clichés, and is literally a physical pain to play. I would love to play this game more, but only if I knew I would be able to finish it without deafaning/blinding myself. If this game were changed only slightly to tweak these issues I really think it could be great.

34806564.review:
Playing the first episode, I was immediately hooked. I love atmospheric stories. The way they used the device of a text adventure (my childhood) and made it extra special through the surrounding environment, impressed me. At the end of that first episode, I let out a deep sigh and said, damn. That was a good story. Can't wait to play the rest. 

I enjoyed the second one almost as much. Atmospheric story puzzler. Nice. Ditto the third. The kind of puzzles that make you feel smart but aren't hard enough to need a walkthrough. The atmosphere was solid the whole way through.

And then I played the fourth episode. And now I'm gobsmacked. 

The whole thing is woven together so tight, and I didn't even know I was playing right into it the narrative the whole time. Masterful. If you like a tight story, with creepy little hints that tie all together,  I suggest not reading anothe review or watching a trailer or getting any spoilers. Just boot up the game, turn out the lights, turn up your headphones, and don't leave the screen until your done. You can beat it without a walkthrough. 

That ending is a doozy, though.

34779915.review:
[i]J'aurai mieux fait de ne pas les connaitre ces histoires...[/i]

[b]Stories Untold[/b], sorti en 2017, est une compilation de 4 petites histoires. (Difficile d'en dire plus, au risque de tout gâcher)

[h1]Les plus :[/h1]

- Et bien, l'ambiance pesante, un peu horror parfois, est réussie, avec un petit côté paranormal.. On vit l'histoire.
- La bande-son est énorme, réaliste, et prend aux tripes !
- Les histoires, où l'on ne comprends rien au début, prennent toutes leurs sens à la fin, vous laissant bouche bée, sur le c*l, vous repassant tous les épisodes en tête, en vous disant : [i]"Ah oui... C'est donc pour ça que ça..."[/i]
- Le gameplay varie en fonction des épisodes, mais on reste sur du text-based, du Point&Click et de la Réflexion.
- Graphiquement très propre, fait sous Unity.
- La narration est vraiment parfaite, vivante, et bien jouée.

[h1]Les moins :[/h1]

- Pas de VF. Très embêtant pour les anglophobes, surtout pour les passages text-based.
- La petite phase de FPS un peu boguée dans les escaliers...

[h1]N.B. :[/h1]

- Environ 3h pour finir le jeu. Tout dépend de votre facilité à résoudre les énigmes (plus ou moins simple)

[h1]Conclusion :[/h1]

[b]Stories Untold[/b] est un excellent jeu narratif, avec une histoire obscure, intriguante, mélée à un gameplay simple et efficace, et des énigmes travaillées. Je le recommande cependant aux personnes maitrisant un minimum l'anglais.

_ _ _ _

[h1]Si vous avez trouvé cette évaluation utile, venez rejoindre notre [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/AlternaTyff#curation]page de curation et nos forums ![/url][/h1]

34767222.review:
It's a rather strange horror game made on a junction of text adventure, puzzle and first-person point & click genres. I'd say it's a truly unique mix which you wouldn't normally encounter anywhere else. At start, you may think it tells you separate unrelated stories which suddenly bends in the least expected ways, but they actually are related and converge into a rather sad one. However, you won't understand how is that possible until you get to the last one.

The only real issue with this game is the length which is really-really short. You may easily finish it in a 2-3 hours unless you stuck at something not really obvious and absolutely don't want to use a guide (which is a right decision, BTW). I'm not sure if it worth a full price due to the length, but with a decent discount it really does. On the other hand where will you find anything else like this?

34752174.review:
Stories Untold is a rather odd game from Devolver Digital, which seems to sort of be their thing. At first, it appears to be some sort of weird text adventure thing, though in a “game within a game” sort of environment, as you are playing the game on a computer on a desk inside your computer.

The game has a very 1980s vibe to it, which isn’t surprising, because it is set in 1986. It reminds me somewhat of the 1980s Twilight Zone, or similar shows; the first story immediately makes you realize that the game is going to be rather meta, but the game has a number of additional twists in store as you go through its four episodes.

That being said, I use the term “game” somewhat loosely here; this is a strictly linear storytelling experience, and is almost entirely concerned with following directions rather than solving puzzles or interacting with the environment in any sort of meaningful way. Rather, this is more like an interactive made-for-TV movie, or perhaps miniseries – and it is about as long as one, too, clocking in at about 2 hours and 15 minutes to complete.

While this seems to be a horror game at first, it is not the “random monster jumps out and scares you” kind of horror, and while the first episode does a reasonable job of messing with you, the later ones become much less creepy, though all of them have at least somewhat worrisome aesthetics to them.

As the game goes on, increasingly more gameplay mechanics are added, and while the game never becomes complex, and you never really do much more than follow directions, the extremely limited adventure game text interface is actually limited to only a couple portions of the game.

All that being said, this is a very, very simple game. While this is not a walking simulator, this is still a very narrative-focused game with very little actual gameplay, perhaps more like a visual novel than anything else, though its interface is, if anything, most reminiscent of Don’t Touch Anything in terms of being in a very narrowly confined space most of the time, with just one or two screens of actual “content” per episode (though the finale is more complicated).

Sadly, said interface is also clunky at times; the text adventure sections are particularly frustrating at times due to the fact that the interface is not always very smart about what you’re telling it to do, and there were a couple points where I struggled to do what I was trying to do due to needing to find the “magic words” so to speak.

The only other major problem with the game is the fact that, in the end, the story as it ultimately pans out isn’t really nearly as twisty as you would have hoped based on all the other twists in the game. In fact, I was rather disappointed with the ending, as I was hoping that there was going to be one more twist, or rather, that what you were being pushed towards was not what had really happened, but was yet another lie. Alas, it was missing that extra layer, which I think might have added something more to the experience.

All in all, I feel like this was one of those things that tried, but didn't quite get there. If you’re looking for gameplay, this is probably not the place to go looking. And if you aren’t super enamored with dark stories with dark twist endings, this isn’t likely to be up your alley either. If you like a 1980s vibe, though, and a darker sort of vibe, this might be something you’d be interested in. It is certainly a different sort of game.

This is certainly quite a unique experience for me in terms of storytelling.

The stories are linked together being played in sequence, each introducing some difference in terms of how you interact with the story. The story does tell of a lesson that would have been best learnt without experiencing in the real world.

Some of the aspects of the game that I feel could use some work are:
1. The text based reponse prominent in the first story is somewhat hard to get around. There is no indication on how we could interact and move within the story and it mostly came down to trial and error to get the neccessary responses. 
2. The puzzles that are introduced are managable but does lack some explaination and clarifications. Some puzzle involves sounds and images that are hard to hear or look at and did prove some challenge for me in understanding and decifering.
3. I did feel that the pace of the game was somewhat broken whenever we were given the apportunity to move. In my opinion it would have been better if there was no movement required from me as a player.

The game does feel more like experiments looking into different combinations that would provide a good storytelling experience, rather than a full game. All in all the experience from this game was interesting but considering how short the game is I would only recommend buying on a discount.

34714618.review:
Tras dudarlo un rato le voy a dar un pulgar hacia abajo porque aunque he disfrutado el juego no tengo claro que lo pueda recomendar. ¿Por qué? Porque lo he disfrutado más como una pieza experimental, para ver las posibilidades en temas de aventuras conversacionales para el mundo moderno, que como juego en sí. La historia está bien, resulta interesante, pero la sensación de estar siguiendo las instrucciones para escuchar una historia 'en raíles' es demasiado fuerte y eso destroza, desde mi punto de vista, el posible interés general en la obra. Así que a tu propio riesgo si después de leer esto te lo compras. 

¿De qué va el juego? Pues el juego recrea cuatro episodios de una serie de televisión al estilo 'Dimensión Desconocida' que aparentemente están desconectados entre sí pero que en el episoido final veremos que son parte de la misma historia (de hecho hay pistas en cada episodio, pero hay que estar atento). 

Las mecánicas consisten básicamente en interaccionar con unas pantallas mediante clicks de ratón (pulsar botones, activar palanquitas de encendido, etc) y en algunas partes realizar acciones a través de una línea de comandos al estilo de las viejas aventuras conversacionales. Esta parte fue la que más me gustó, sin duda, pero tiene trampa: aunque el primer capítulo (que es la demo) es así el resto del juego no sigue ese formato. 

El juego está en inglés y hay que dominarlo para disfrutarlo. Eso no va a ser una sorpresa para nadie teniendo en cuenta que parte del juego consiste en usar un interface al estilo de las viejas aventuras conversacionales. Pero a eso debemos sumar que hay ocasiones en las que deberemos escuchar voces en off sin subtítulo (pese a que haya esa opción) que nos dicen números para descifrar claves. Así que la primera pared es el idioma. 

Otra cosa que odio es que no se puede grabar en medio cada capítulo. Los capítulos son cortos (se completan en unos veinte minutos cada uno, menos si sabes las instrucciones concretas) pero hay uno en concreto, el de las estaciones árticas, que es un rollo de andar a mirar claves en un microfilm. Y la verdad es que es una puñeta llevar tres o cuatro claves descifradas y que tengas que dejar por cualquier motivo la partida (por ejemplo que te llame alguien para ir a algún sitio) para empezar de cero otra vez. Además cada vez que empiezas un capítulo te tienes que tragar la intro de la serie y las partes de voz (les llamaría cinemáticas pero no lo son). Personalmente odio los juegos que tienen tan poca consideración por sus jugadores, no costaba nada permitir grabar la posición.

Otro problema es que, como dije al principio, es un maldito pasillo a nivel 'gameplay'. Me las prometía feliz improvisando cosas, experimentando... pero en realidad tienes que hacer lo que los programadores han decidido en el orden que lo han decidido, sin saltarte nada. Tiene su lógica cuando termina la historia pero aún así creo que había soluciones narrativas mucho más interesantes. Es muy frustrante la carencia total de libertad.

Además el 'parser' (la programación que controla las instrucciones que entiende el juego) es muy malo. Entiende muy pocas cosas. No habría costado absolutamente nada mejorarlo. Y lo sé porque he trabajado y programado parsers de aventuras conversacionales (de ahí que me interesase tanto este título). Hay una dejadez preocupante en la cantidad de sinónimos, palabras y combinaciones que han dejado en manos del comodín 'no entiendo lo que dices'. 

¿Pero no decía que lo había disfrutado? Pues sí, es cierto. Pese a sus cosas malas me aferro a las buenas.

Las historias son interesantes. Tanto las historias sueltas, de los capítulos de la serie, como la propia historia final. No son el colmo de la originalidad ni tampoco te voy a decir que te vayan a hacer estallar la cabeza, pero están bien construídas y despiertan el suficiente interés como para querer jugar hasta el final. 

La apuesta es arriesgada. Respeto eso. Trasladar la idea de las aventuras conversacionales a una época donde hay gente que amenaza con arrancarse los ojos si algo no tiene un framerate de 60 es todo un logro. Y me alegro que Devolver, como siempre, siga apostando por el mercado indie alternativo.

Es una pena que el conjunto del juego no fuera como el primer capítulo. De haber sido así seguramente lo recomendaría aún pese a sus defectos.

Decisamente consigliato per chi vuole provare qualcosa di nuovo

34704333.review: I wanted to love this game. I loved the old text based adventure games and was surprised to see a new one, especially in my favorite genre: horror. The interface was perfect for the atmosphere and I was settled in ready to enjoy being creeped out. Then I played it. Ugh. In classic text based adventures, they had to make it understand a wide variety of commands and give responses to them. If you found a lock and typed "Smash lock" it might tell you the lock wouldn't break or you bashed and couldn't dent it. Something to make you feel like you were really there, even if you didn't put in the choice they wanted. And in a psychological horror game, that immersion is vital. Instead, I recieved a steady stream of "I don't understand"s. And when the tension is highest is when the game gives the least leeway in your commands. The story might tell you an object is in another room, but ignores your attmpts to enter the room and instead expects you to know you can interact with the object. With how far technology has come, I thought we might be at a place where text based adventures would be more immesive, not less. Sadly, I must give the thumbs down to a game i wanted so badly to be my new favorite game to talk about....

34700250.review:
Stories Untold is exceptionally original in its take on a text-based horror game. Split up into 4 episodes, each episode is about 30-45 minutes long. However, the quality and direction of the different episodes changes drastically. The first episode is an absolute blast to play, and sets extremely high expectations for the rest of the game.

Unfortunately, the other episodes don't quite measure up. The 2nd episode is tolerable, but the 3rd episode is a slog fest that will have you shift-tabbing into a walkthrough just to get through it faster. The 4th episode is a revisit of the previous three, with a big reveal that ultimately seems underwhelming for what you were put through to get there. That being said, the finale is disturbing and keeps you on the edge of your seat for a fair portion of it.

Gameplay aside, this game does have a few technical and mechanical issues. The screen real estate is realistic but impractical. The terminals in the game only take up maybe a third of the screen, and there are often bright lights in the other sections. On smaller screen (such as laptops) this can be frustrating as the text is hard to read.

Ultimately, the game as a whole is only slightly above average. However, the novelty and the sheer intensity of the first and last episodes make me remember it fondly.

34700009.review: A quick game, but the story was not what I was expecting.  I do not think that the horror tag is accurate at all.  Well worth the cost of the game though!

34698891.review: Pretty good game- really enjoyed, BUT did NOT appreciate the 2nd episode continually shinning a light in my eyes- seriously?? Why couldn't my POV move so that it wasn't not continually in my face? I had to put a large box in the corner of my screen, just to block out the bright shinning light. Otherwise, good game.

34698610.review:
Ok, una cosa que he de admitir de entrada: el juego ya me compró con su primer trailer y poster apenas presentados.

Es cierto, las obvias "inspiraciones" estéticas a productos como "Stranger Things" son evidentes. Pero ¿Acaso no es ese show a la vez un conjunto de "inspiraciones" de diferentes íconos ochentosos que tanto amamos y añoramos aquellos que contamos con algunas décadas encima?

Ahora, en cuanto al juego. Podría definírselo como una aventura de texto con algunos tintes de puzzle y exploración. 4 episodios presentados como un show televisivo (muy a lo "Dimensión Desconocida") en donde pasaremos la mayor parte del tiempo tipeando frente a algún tipo de ordenador. Y aquí un punto muy importante: [b]El juego está en inglés y probablemente nunca tenga una traducción[/b], por lo cual si no manejan el idioma ni se molesten en jugarlo. En cuanto a los puzzles (en los momentos en que están presentes), los mismos resultan bastante simples e involucran mayormente explorar el entorno e interactuar con determinados objetos.

Si bien todos los episodios pueden desbloquearse de entrada para jugarse en el orden de presferencia de uno, es [u] altamente recomendable[/u] seguir el orden establecido, ya que las historias que en principio parecen estar desconectadas entre sí podrían en realidad estar más ligadas de lo que uno creería (y es todo lo que diré al respecto para no entrar en el terreno del spoiler).
La atmósfera está muy bien creada, desde la música y los efectos sonoros hasta el voice acting y el apartado visual.

Cada episodio está pensado para jugarse de una pasada (razón por la cual probablemente no se cuente con la opción de grabar la partida en ningún momento). De hecho, es probable que todo el juego pueda pasarse de una sentada (con un gameplay total que oscilará entre las 3 y 4 horas). Y he ahí quizás uno de los factores que le juegue en contra: tenemos cero rejugabilidad, a no ser por el mero hecho de querer revivir la experiencia. Pero aún si se lo jugara una sola vez para nunca más volver a tocarlo la experiencia habrá valido la pena.

Lo disfruté, y mucho. Es una de las primeras cosas que el estudio No Code desarrolla, y desde ya estaré atento a seguir sus nuevos proyectos.
